column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/231270,2023,Low control designs: Field Research,English,"Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. Y. Rahmouni Elidrissi, PhD', 'O.N. Alakavuklar, MA']",,"Course goals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• have practical, theoretical and philosophical knowledge about methods that can be used while working with low control designs;
• can reflect on their own experiences of getting access to an organisation and to one or more research participants;

• are knowledgeable about and able to carry out different data collection methods, e.g. shadowing, interviewing, participatory photography, participant observation, online ethnography and sensory ethnography;
• are aware of ethical and political issues that can arise while doing fieldwork;
• will be able to use different ways of writing up data, e.g. transcriptions of interviews, making an observation report and writing field notes;
• are able to reflect on the advantages, disadvantages and differences between several methods for collecting data within field research;
• are able to organise data for analysis.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Ethnographic fieldwork is ‘in the moment’ observation of and engagement with unfolding phenomena in their natural setting. In this course you will learn to conduct field research in organisations: to design, gain access, gather data and organise data for analysis. You will be sensitised to the politics and ethics of fieldwork, which given the close proximity of the researcher to the object of study, can be particularly vexing.

In several meetings you will employ different ways of collecting data through small assignments. We will discuss the strengths and weaknesses of each method, the implications of the chosen theoretical framework on data collection and ethical issues that can arise while conducting qualitative research.

In another part of the course you will enter the field. Assignments entail that you have to gain access to an organisation and engage in participant observation, interviewing, participatory photography and sensory ethnography. The collected data will be presented for discussion in class.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Aan het eind van deze cursus in de student in staat om:

column2: • de pathogenese is van Allergische Rhinitis, Astma en COPD uit te leggen
• van een aantal representatieve farmaca aan te geven wat de aangrijpingspunten zijn en wat de relatie hiervan is tot werking en bijwerkingen
• de werking van de bij luchtwegaandoeningen gebruikte inhalatoren te begrijpen
• de relatie tussen de wijze waarop het geneesmiddel in de luchtwegen wordt toegediend (o.a. deeltjesgrootte) en de werking te beschrijven
• de farmacotherapeutische mogelijkheden en het beleid bij Allergische Rhinitis, Astma en COPD te beschrijven
• de basisconcepten van mondelinge communicatie rondom het geven doelgroep gerichte informatie toe te passen
• aan te geven welke fysiologische processen een rol spelen bij de ademhaling
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De cursus Luchtwegaandoeningen en medicatie is een keuzecursus in het tweede jaar van de bachelor Farmacie. In deze cursus staat de medicamenteuze behandeling van Allergische Rhinitis, Astma en COPD centraal. De cursus grijpt qua inhoud terug op diverse andere cursussen van de bachelor zoals Toedienen van geneesmiddelen, Werking van geneesmiddelen, Therapie met geneesmiddelen, Onderzoek naar geneesmiddelen. De kennis van deze eerdere blokken wordt in de cursus Luchtwegaandoeningen en behandeling geïntegreerd en toegepast op de drie bovengenoemde ziektebeelden.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: À la fin du cours, les étudiant.e.s sont capables de:
- découvrir la structuration diachronique du français en phonétique/phonologie, morphologie, syntaxe et sémantique ;
- s’entraîner à repérer et analyser des spécificités de cette langue ;
- s’initier à la traduction de textes en ancien français ;
- s’initier au médiévalisme, c’est-à-dire à la discipline scientifique qui étudie la réutilisation de la langue et culture médiévales dans la culture contemporaine ;
- analyser les expressions contemporaines reprenant le monde médiéval à l’aide des notions théoriques telles que « retraduction », « réinterprétation » et « adaptation ». </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Ce cours vise à présenter les caractéristiques principales de l’ancien français entre les XIIe-XVe siècles et les répercussions de cette langue ancienne sur la culture française contemporaine. Par l’intermédiaire d’exercices portant sur des extraits d’œuvres médiévales variées, on abordera des questions de traduction et de retraduction, de phonétique/phonologie, de morphologie, de syntaxe, de sémantique, de réinterprétation et d’adaptation. Il s’agira par là de se familiariser avec la langue française médiévale, sa structure et ses spécificités, ainsi qu’avec son héritage, c’est-à-dire une sélection de représentations post-médiévales de la langue et de la culture médiévales, généralement désignées par le mot « médiévalisme ».

Ce cours donné en français est ouvert au programme ‘lingua receptiva’. Cela signifie que les étudiants.e.s qui sont à même de comprendre la langue française à un niveau B2, compréhension orale et écrite, mais ne possèdent pas les qualités suffisantes pour la production orale et écrite, peuvent prendre part au cours. Les examens seront menés en anglais ou en néerlandais. Si vous êtes intéressé.e par le concept, merci de prendre contact immédiatement après votre inscription avec l’enseignant.e. Attention: si vous choisissez la variante ‘lingua receptiva’, le cours sera inclus dans l’espace profile de votre département d’origine. Le cours ne peut donc pas compter en tant que cours ‘langue spécifique’ au sein de l’orientation majeure ou mineure de votre département.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completion of the thesis trajectory, the student is capable
A) to demonstrate the necessary analytical and writing skills to present a theoretically sound and intersectionally developed argument in Gender Studies;
B) to present and use in practice a feminist methodological framework;
C) to formulate clearly the central research question of the thesis and provide a convincing answer to it in the thesis;
D) to bring the academic insights of Gender Studies to the professional and societal field.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The final project consists of a written assignment (thesis) that is related to the internship and, therefore, aimed at the professional practice of Gender Studies. The thesis needs to suffice in all academic standards (scientific originality and significance, theoretical-methodological framework, thorough analysis of a case study). Students formulate a clear research question based on the knowledge gained throughout their studies and the questions raised during the internship. For the process of writing the thesis, students will be supervised by a staff member (mentor/supervisor).</body>

column3: The MA-thesis is the result of independent research on a topic pertaining to the Master Literature Today. It is to give proof of knowledge and skills acquired over the course of the Master program. In the MA-thesis, the student demonstrates his/her abilities to phrase a clear and manageable research question, conduct research independently in order to respond to that question, and to report the findings in the form of an academic text of high quality (clear structure, clear and correct writing, scholarly use of sources).</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The MA-thesis gives academic proof of competence and knowledge in the field(s) studied within the Master Literature Today. The student demonstrates that s/he is able to conduct independent research in the field(s) of study and is able to analyse and critically evaluate a phenomenon or question pertaining to the relevant scholarly debates. The final product is a written exposition of said research, which has to fulfill the scholarly and formal requirements for advanced MA-research. The final product has to be clearly structured, presenting the discussion of a central research question and provide an answer to it.

The aim of the thesis is to allow students:
- to acquire the ability to carry out their own comparative or long-term historical research project in the field of the history of politics and society
- to apply to their research project appropriate theories, concepts and methods
- to report on their research according to academic standards</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The topic of the thesis (c. 12,500 words) should be related to one of the core themes of the MA-programme. Students will be offered a choice from several topics, such as: democracy, citizenship, collective action, the welfare state, civil society, and capitalism/the market. Students are expected to use the theories and methods acquired during the MA-programme. Preparation for the thesis takes place as part of the course Themes in the History of Politics and Society, for which students will be expected to write an outline of their thesis and the introductory chapter.
Before starting your thesis you need to have completed the following courses:
GKMV22002 Politics and Society in Comparative Perspective or GKMV17015 Toolbox
GKMV17016 Themes in the History of Politics and Society
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/228557,2023,MA: Energy: Politics, infrastructure and change",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['N. Wiegink'],,"Course goals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of the course you are able:

column2: • To analyze academic and societal debates about energy from an anthropological perspective, and develop a sound critical and scientific position of your own.
• To critically evaluate and compare various conceptual approaches on energy within anthropology.
• To apply conceptual approaches on energy in anthropology to empirical case-studies and your surroundings.
• Design a small research project and experiment with ethnographic research methods.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Energy: Politics, Infrastructure, and Change examines energy from an anthropological perspective. In this course we will think critically about the systems that literally power our world(s). We will discuss the theoretical, methodological, and practical contributions that an anthropological perspective can bring to a subject that often appears to be a matter of science, technology, and design. Based on ethnographic representations of energy extraction, production, distribution, and consumption, we will delve into questions of power and political ecology by addressing the role of energy in (state) governance, conflict, extractivism, inequalities, and forms of contestation. We will explore energy landscapes (actual and imagined) in which infrastructure and human relationships come together and address how these are historically and culturally situated and globally connected. We will study energy transitions through ethical questions, political visions, desires, and identities that are invested in energy futures.

The structure of the course centers around three main activities: 1. Lectures, supported by visual material; 2. Student-led section meetings providing in-depth discussions of the literature and applied on specific cases; 3. A short research assignment for which you will apply anthropological perspectives on energy to your surroundings and experiment with ethnographic research methods. The assignment will result in a research paper.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The master thesis information session is for students who plan to start their MBIM thesis project.
The session  is a short meeting  offered 4 times a year, at the beginning of each teaching period.
Students are strongly advised to attend the meeting at the beginning of the year they intend  to finalize their program.
The session will cover the thesis project’s setup and requirements.  Q&A is an important part of the meeting.
Points that will be addressed in the information session:

column2: • project phases (when which step to take) and registration forms
• submitting the thesis project proposal in Osiris Case

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/232841,2023,MH1: Current issues in health care: the historical context,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,['prof. dr. A.B.J. Prakken'],,Content

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In deze cursus staat een merkwaardige paradox van de moderne gezondheidszorg centraal. Enerzijds geldt dat we nog nooit zo lang (gezond) hebben geleefd, dat we nog nooit over zoveel medische kennis hebben beschikt en dat we nog nooit zoveel mensen en middelen hebben ingezet voor geneeskunde en zorg als tegenwoordig. Anderzijds is sprake van groeiende schaarste in de zorg, van ongelijke toegang tot de zorg, van een groeiende obsessie met gezondheid (healthism) en van vele mensen die hun toevlucht nemen tot complementaire en alternatieve behandelingen. Hoe is deze paradox te verklaren? In deze cursus worden de vragen en problemen van vandaag inzichtelijk gemaakt door ze in een langetermijnperspectief te plaatsen. De westerse medische traditie is bijna 3000 jaar oud. Wat werd in het verleden als de primaire taak van de arts gezien? Waardoor is dat veranderd, en hoe? Welke doelen streefde de geneeskunde voorheen na, en hoe zit dat tegenwoordig? Op welke manier werd kennis over het menselijk lichaam vergaard - zowel in gezondheid als in ziekte – en hoe gaat dat nu? Wat was de rol van de overheid in de gezondheidszorg - zowel in preventieve als in curatieve zin – en hoe is dat tegenwoordig geregeld?   Studenten worden uitgedaagd om antwoorden te formuleren op deze even urgente als complexe vragen. De master Medical Humanities identificeert zes uitdagingen, die in deze cursus worden gepresenteerd en in latere cursussen verder zullen worden uitgewerkt. De uitdagingen worden geïntroduceerd in de vorm van vragen bij (van tevoren bestudeerde) historische kunst en medisch erfgoed aanwezig in de universitaire collecties in Utrecht, waarbij steeds de micro- en de macro-dimensies van de verschillende uitdagingen belicht worden. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na afloop van deze cursus kan de student
- De juiste onderzoeksvraag stellen om specifieke, complexe problemen in de gezondheidszorg verder te onderzoeken met behulp van specifieke en passende methoden
- Antwoorden op onderzoeksvragen juist en kritisch interpreteren

- Uitleggen wat het verschil is tussen diverse typen onderzoeksmethoden, binnen welk kader deze onderzoeksmethoden functioneren en waarom dat zo is - Verschillende onderzoeksmethoden binnen meerdere paradigma's (kwantitatief-kwalitatief; vragenlijsten-interview-bronnenonderzoek) evalueren en bevragen omdat ze de voor- en nadelen van een breed arsenaal aan onderzoeksmethoden kennen
- Samenwerken in een interdisciplinair team van onderzoekers
- Een interdisciplinair onderzoeksvoorstel schrijven en presenteren over actuele of toekomstige uitdagingen in de gezondheidszorg, gebruikmakend van een of meerdere methoden die de student beheerst

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In de cursus ‘MH4: huidige en toekomstige uitdagingen in de gezondheidszorg: interdisciplinaire onderzoeksvaardigheden’ leer je kritisch redeneren over specifieke disciplinaire onderzoeksvaardigheden, leer je een interdisciplinair onderzoek opzetten en presenteren en leer je reflecteren op interdisciplinariteit. Je zult aan de hand van voorbeelden verschillende onderzoeksmethoden leren kennen en je leert welke onderzoeksvragen aansluiten bij welke onderzoeksmethoden. Je zult je verdiepen in een van de methoden en daarbij kritisch redeneren over de voor- en nadelen hiervan. Je werkt samen in een interdisciplinair team om een interdisciplinaire vraag uit te werken over een onderwerp binnen actuele en toekomstige uitdagingen in de gezondheidszorg. Naar aanleiding van deze uitwerking kies je individueel een specifieke vraag en stel je in een onderzoeksvoorstel een methode voor om deze vraag te beantwoorden. </body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/232600,2023,MH5: Optimal communication: interaction and narrativity in healthcare,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,[],,Content

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In de gezondheidszorg speelt communicatie een cruciale rol: tussen professionals en patiënten, tussen professionals onderling, maar ook diverse andere stakeholders spelen een grote rol. De uitdagingen zijn legio: van patiënten die schriftelijke communicatie van het ziekenhuis niet begrijpen tot mislukte overdrachtsmomenten tussen professionals omdat ze minimaal communiceren. In deze cursus gaat het om de grondslagen van optimale communicatie: begrijpelijkheid en overtuigingskracht. Studenten analyseren concrete teksten, interacties en situaties, en herontwerpen communicatieve uitingen en strategieën op grond van die analyse. Daarbij wordt bijzondere aandacht besteed aan de context waarin de communicatie plaats vindt. Vaak worden patiënten gehinderd door een lage gezondheidsgeletterdheid, of is sprake van interculturele verschillen die tot miscommunicatie leiden. Bovendien bestaat het zorglandschap uit meerdere partijen; denk aan medici en paramedici, familieleden, vrienden en collega’s, maar ook een zorgverzekeraar, ziekenhuis of patiëntenvereniging. Al deze belanghebbenden (stakeholders) kijken vanuit hun eigen perspectief naar de zorg en maken deel uit van een breder netwerk van connecties en belangen. Studenten leren daarvan netwerkanalyses te maken en dit te vertalen naar een narratief. Door alle perspectieven zo goed mogelijk naar voren te brengen, te begrijpen en vervolgens te integreren in de vorm van een overkoepelend en synthetiserend verhaal (co-constructed narrative), zullen studenten tot een completer, genuanceerder en duidelijker beeld van een specifiek zorgnetwerk komen. De kracht van narratieven verdient bijzondere aandacht in deze cursus: wat is het verhaal van de patiënt als je goed luistert? Hoe zijn narratieven bruikbaar om mensen zo begrijpelijk en overtuigend mogelijk te informeren over gezond gedrag?  In de cursus wordt getraind in analytische en communicatieve vaardigheden, waaronder interviewtechnieken en tekstherziening. Uiteindelijk kunnen studenten vanuit een contextuele netwerkanalyse bestaande communicatiesituaties beoordelen en optimaliseren, waarbij beter wederzijds begrip van de verschillende stakeholders de doelstelling is. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na afloop van deze cursus kan de student:

1) Diverse gezondheidscrises op populatieniveau in internationale en nationale context benoemen, daarover een onderbouw standpunt innemen, en identificeren hoe de thema’s zich verhouden tot health equity;
2) Benoemen hoe bepaalde Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) zich verhouden tot gezondheid in het algemeen en geestelijke gezondheid in het bijzonder;

3) Communiceren over de gezondheidsdoelen (SDG3) en manieren om deze te behalen, met verschillende doelgroepen (op basis van leeftijd, culturele achtergrond, opleiding, professie, in diplomatieke context van de VN);
4) Bespreken wat de verschillen en overeenkomsten zijn tussen public health en global health.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Als Covid-19, de klimaatcrisis en de groeiende ongelijkheid in de wereld iets duidelijk maken, dan is het wel dat mensen en regio's meer dan ooit met elkaar verbonden zijn. Om de complexiteit van het hedendaagse gezondheidsdomein analytisch te ontrafelen, kijken we binnen dit vak naar gezondheid op populatieniveau, in internationale en nationale context. Dit doen we vanuit een health equity lens, waarbij het gaat om gelijke kansen op gezondheid voor iedereen. Bij deze analyse gebruiken we de Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) van de Verenigde Naties als uitgangspunt. We kijken hoe deze doelen samenhangen met gezondheid, en welke stappen er worden genomen om de doelen te behalen. Op nationaal niveau in Nederland gaan we kijken naar geestelijke gezondheid. Hoe kunnen we de 'GGZ-crisis' beter begrijpen? Studenten gaan erover met elkaar in gesprek. Ook gaan zij erover schrijven voor verschillende doelgroepen.

column1: The topic could be theoretical or practical, could include fieldwork and/or lab-work and/or computer-based simulation/modelling. The various options include: a work placement in a company or government organisation working in Earth Sciences or participating in university research. In consultation with the proposed supervisors - one internal supervisor (teacher) and one external supervisor (from the organisation offering the training), an internship proposal should be formulated. This should also contain details of credits involved (ECTS), time-planning, deliverables (reports/presentations), confidentiality aspects etc. to avoid last-minute surprises on all sides. The internship request form and proposal MUST be submitted for PRIOR approval to, first, the internal supervisor, and then the internship coordinator who will pass it for final approval. If the internship is also to be used for the mandatory graduation research, the internship proposal should also be submitted to the coordinator of the relevant for PRIOR approval.

According to the examination rules and regulations with regards to the MSc programme ESW, a student should first hand in a first version of his/her MSc graduation thesis before he/she is allowed to start off with an internship/guided research.
More information and required forms are available on Blackboard enter the page on Blackbaord https://uu.blackboard.com/ and look for “guided research” or 'internship"".

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In addition to the Graduation Research, all Earth Sciences MSc students have to perform a second individual project. When conducting a Guided Research project, the student demonstrates advanced knowledge in the field of the MSc programmes and skills to pursue independent research. These skills include:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: A Guided Research is similar to an MSc Research project but the expectations regarding the autonomy and independence of the student in a Guided Research project are lower. This applies particularly to developing the research objectives and methodology. Furthermore, an oral presentation of the results is not obligatory and not part of the assessment.

The topic of the Guided Research has to fit within, or has strong links with, one of the Earth Sciences programmes. The methodology can be based on literature studies but can also include practical activities such as: fieldwork, lab-work or computer-based simulation/modelling. In any case, a permanent member of the scientific staff of the department of Earth Sciences or Physical Geography is responsible for the supervision and research assessment. Postdocs and PhD-students may be involved in the daily supervision and can act as second supervisors. It is possible that the Guided Research project is performed at another academic or non-academic institution. In this case, a staff member at the host institution will be in charge of the daily supervision who is typically then also the second supervisor. If the project does not involve a second supervisor, a second reviewer has to be assigned to the project. Typically, the second reviewer is only involved in the assessment of the report. However, the second reviewer takes over the responsibilities of the first supervisor if necessary.

As part of the project prepares an individual report written in English. This report is a stand-alone document and it is inadmissible that it text overlaps with any other report/thesis, including those produced by the student himself/herself.
The credit load of a Guided Research can vary between 7.5 and 30 ECTS credits in steps of 7.5 ECTS credits.

Before starting a Guided Research project, the project has to be agreed by the first supervisor and approved by the Teaching Institute Earth Sciences. A project agreement form needs to be filled out, signed and send to the Teaching Institute via an online webform, which is available in the Guided Research community on Blackboard. The following information needs to be provided:

column2: • The name and affiliation of a second reviewer
• Host institution and contact person if applicable.
• Time planning of the project including start and finish date ulation of the total number of working hours.

column1: In case that the Guided Research project involves fieldwork, the proposal also includes the signed Declaration regarding safety and behavior during excursions and fieldwork. Note that assessing the risks of the planned MSc fieldwork and discussing these risks with the student is the task of the supervisor and part of the safety procedure.
The proposal has to be signed by the student, the first supervisor

During the project, it is expected that the student does all in his/her power to fulfill the commitments agreed on in the Guided Research proposal and to ensure that the progress of the project is as planned. A delay in finalizing the MSc project of more than four weeks after the intended end date has to be reported and justified by the student to the Teaching Institute. A request of postponing the date of completion has to be supported by the supervisor and has to include an updated time planning. Delayed completion of the Guided Research project without approval by the supervisor can lead to its rejection.

At the end of the Guided Research project, the first supervisor/examiner grades the MSc thesis project. After sufficient feedback and discussion, the first supervisor/examiner grades the Guided research project. The final assessment is discussed and approved by the second reviewer/examiner. The assessment and grading of the Guided research project will be based on the Guided research Rubric Earth Sciences. A final mark of 8.5 or higher will only be approved if it is supported by a third reviewer. This third reviewer a) should be an expert in the field of the guided research; b) should not have been involved in any way in the project and/or writing stage; c) may be a university lecturer or professional from outside Utrecht University; d) is expected to provide a short written statement.
Further information including the required forms can be found in the Guided Research community on Blackboard (https://uu.blackboard.com)
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/228221,2023,MSc thesis writing seminar,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. J.G. de Kruijf'],,Course goals

In-depth knowledge of the format of anthropological texts.
Thorough understanding of the epistemological significance and         empirical         evidence         of         the         anthropological         approach.

Reflection on the relation between theory and data - Development of         oral         presentation         skills         and         the         chairing         of         seminar         discussions.
Development of academic writing skills through the writing of         preliminary         versions         of         the         M.Sc.         thesis.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This seminar teaches students how to improve the structure, narrative, clarity, and style of writing, while addressing problems such as writer's block and bibliographic overload. It allows students to build up the confidence that they have significant research data which need to be reported in a scientific style to allow them to communicate with the academic community. The seminar provides students with a biweekly forum to discuss and demonstrate their progress in writing their M.Sc. theses. Students will distribute drafts in advance to allow two discussants to make extensive comments, and make students benefit from the input of peers and instructors to write a high-quality thesis.
An effort is made to schedule seminars on Thurdays. For a biweekly class schedule, please consult the course manual.
Utrecht University has an official course commitment policy. This policy consists of:

column5: 80% attendance in seminars (only a maximum of 20% absence is accepted, irrespective of the reasons).
Handing in papers and assignments on time; and
Obligatory participation in seminars.

column3: There exists no collective possibility to resubmit rewritten papers. Only students who have complied with all commitment policy requirements will be given one additional chance to submit a rewritten paper within three weeks after the course ended. Resubmission is not a right of students but a privilege given by the course coordinator on a case-to-case basis, and therefore require his permission.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Bij  succesvolle deelname en afronding van de cursus beschikt de student over:
1) overzicht over de beroepsvelden waarop de master voorbereidt en de concrete (onderzoeks)stages en (onderzoeks)projecten waar later in de opleiding aan kan worden deelgenomen;

2) inzicht in de manier waarop taalwetenschappelijke onderzoeksmethoden en maatschappelijke vragen in de praktijk bij elkaar komen en leiden tot taalkundig gemotiveerde adviezen, interventies of beleidsmaatregelen;
3) inzicht in de algemene vaardigheden die belangrijk zijn voor het succesvol functioneren als taalkundige professional en deze vaardigheden deels al ontwikkelen;
4) schrijfvaardigheid in het Nederlands op academisch niveau.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De cursus plaatst het taalkundige onderzoek naar meertaligheid en taalverwerving in het perspectief van de verschillende manieren waarop dat onderzoek in maatschappelijke domeinen kan worden toegepast. Taalkundig onderzoek vormt de basis voor taaldiagnostiek, taalonderwijs, taaladviezen, taalbeleid en taaldocumentatie, toegepast in domeinen die variëren van het tweetalige gezin tot het onderwijs in wereldtalen en de bescherming van streektalen. Tijdens het begeleide met praktijkcomponent (die meestal wordt uitgevoerd als stage) maakt de student kennis met de manier waarop een praktische probleemstelling op basis van taalkundig onderzoek leidt tot adviezen en beleid. In deze cursus wordt de student daarop voorbereid doordat taalkundigen uit de praktijk vertellen hoe zij taalbeleid ontwikkelen en taaladviezen geven in hun eigen domein, op basis van hun onderzoeksexpertise en theoretische kennis. De studenten denken met iedere afzonderlijke case study mee door zich van tevoren in te lezen, vragen te formuleren en na afloop hun bevindingen te rapporteren. Aan het eind van de cursus zijn er voor de student enkele projecten of domeinen in het vizier gekomen die interessant zijn voor het afstudeerproject en waar de student zelf het contact mee gaat uitbouwen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het vak Maat en Integratie is een keuzevak voor wiskundestudenten. Het vak geeft voorkennis voor de studieapaden in Probability and Statistics, Differential equations and Dynamical Systems, maar is ook aan te raden voor alle studenten die in de zuivere wiskunde verder willen gaan (zoals getaltheorie, meetkunde, analyse). Zie voor meer informatie over de studiepaden de studentenwebsite.
Vakinhoud: Lebesgue maat in Euclidischeruimte, maat en integratie in abstract ruimtes, convergentie stellingen, product maat, L^p ruimtes, Radon-Nikodym Theorem.
De volgende onderwerpen zullen behandeld worden in dit vak:

column2: • Stelling van Carathéodory: iedere uitwendige maat induceert een maat.

column1: Integratie met betrekking tot een maat:

column2: • integraal van een functie op een maatruimte,
• limietstellingen voor integralen: Fatou's lemma, monotone en gedomineerde convergentie,
• dichtheid van de continue functies in L^p(\mu) voor de Lebesguemaat,
• productmaat en stellingen van Fubini en Tonelli, verwisseling van de integratievolgorde,
• Stelling van Radon-Nikodym, bestaan van een dichtheidsfunctie

column1: Hoorcolleges (2 x 2 uur per week) en werkcolleges (2 x 2 uur per week).

Het eindcijfer bestaat uit 4 sets inleveropgaven (20%), een deeltentamen (30%) en een eindtentamen (50%). De studenten worden aangemoedigd om bij het oplossen van de inleveropgaven met elkaar te overleggen, maar de uitwerking die een student inlevert moet door hem/haar zelf geschreven en bedacht zijn. Overschrijven van (delen van) uitwerkingen of het door een andere student laten maken van uitwerkingen is plagiaat/fraude en zal gemeld worden bij de examencommissie.

Studenten die een lager cijfer hebben dan een 4 mogen alleen meedoen aan de herkansing als zij voldoen aan de inspanningsverplichting van het vak, te weten: Zij leveren oplossingen voor tenminste de helft van de inleveropgaven in en nemen aan het tentamen deel. Het eindcijfer voor het vak is het cijfer behaald voor de herkansing in geval het vak niet is gehaald na het eindtentamen.
Het vak wordt in het Engels gegeven. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• familiarize with current literature and developments in data stream mining / online machine learning.
• understand Nonstationary Environments: Develop a profound understanding of nonstationary data, including concept drift, covariate shift, and evolving data distributions.
• Adaptive Models: understand the principles and methods behind adaptive machine learning/data stream mining techniques, such as change detection, forgetting, windowing, and adaptive ensembles.
• analyze the relation between different categories of change, processing scenarios and adaptive techniques.
• evaluate the performance of adaptive techniques and reflect on limitations of exemplary approaches.

column1: This research-oriented course integrates formative self-assessment and graded assessments of both, understanding of theory and practical skills.

Throughout the course, there will be given opportunities for self-assessment. These are designed to provide immediate feedback that guides through the learning process and prepare for the later graded assessment.
The graded assessment is done by a written exam.
To qualify for a repair of the final result the mark needs to be at least a 4.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The world is dynamically changing and non-stationary. Among the various types of change that a machine learning system faces in such a dynamic environment, non-stationary data distributions are a common and important challenge.

This phenomenon is denoted as concept or population drift, and has led to the development of dedicated subfields in machine learning and statistics, such as data stream mining, online machine learning, change detection, or change mining/change understanding.

This research-oriented course is designed as advanced course on machine learning/data mining for students with a good knowledge of traditional (stationary, offline) machine learning/data mining techniques, in particular in classification and clustering.

column2: •   categorizing change: Non-stationarity, concept drift, population drift, shift, concept evolution
•   key principles and techniques, such as change detection, windowing, forgetting; chunk-based and one-by-one processing
•   adaptive/online learning methods, in particular for Data Stream Classification, such as Hoeffding Trees or Adaptive Ensembles
•   evaluation and monitoring methodology for non-stationary environments, like out-of-time-evaluation, prequential evaluation, recovery analysis
•   understanding change: Interpretability and explainability in non-stationary environments
•   exemplary frameworks for Data Stream Mining, like RIVER/scikit-multiflow and Massive Online Analysis (MOA)

column1: Selected articles, book chapters, and lecture notes.

column1: In this advanced course about machine learning, we cover several methods for supervised and unsupervised learning, including support vector machines, kernel methods, and advanced techniques used in deep learning. We will go into the underlying mathematical theory, and the precise way in which certain algorithms operate, such as the backpropagation algorithm used to train neural networks.
- Bayesian machine learning: generative models; inference algorithms
- Unsupervised learning: clustering; principal component analysis
- Latent variable models and variational Bayes

column1: You will be able to better understand literature on deep learning and its applications to cognitive science.
You will be in a good position to start gaining hands-on experience in a supervised or team setting, such as an internship or Master’s thesis project.

column2: • students will attend lectures introducing the approach taken in deep learning systems, comparing this to how deep learning is implemented in biological brains, and introducing the main applications of deep learning to cognitive science and linguistics. Their understanding of this content will be assessed in a midterm and a final exam.

column1: Machine learning with deep convolutional neural networks (deep learning) is being applied increasingly broadly in computer science, technology and scientific research.
This method allows computer systems to perform tasks that have previously been impossible or inaccurate for computers, but typically straightforward for humans.

Tasks like visual object identification and natural language processing have traditionally been investigated by cognitive scientists and linguists, but recent applications of deep learning to these tasks also positions them at the center of recent artificial intelligence developments.
Therefore, it is important for AI students and researchers to understand the links between cognitive science and AI.
In this course, you will learn the principles behind deep learning, an approach inspired by the structure of the brain.
You will learn how these principles are implemented in the brain, focusing on the two aspects of visual processing and language (semantic or syntactic) processing.

You will build your own deep learning systems for the interpretation of natural images and language, using modern high-level neural network APIs that make implementation of these systems accessible and efficient.

column1: 1. Je laat in opdrachten en wekelijkse bijeenkomsten je actieve kennis zien over de belangrijkste theorieën van leiderschap.

2. Je bent in staat om belangrijke aspecten van leiderschap, macht, beïnvloeding, en besluitvorming te herkennen in je sociale omgeving en de actualiteit (bv. media, politiek, culturele uitingen) en daarover te rapporteren.
3. Je krijgt inzicht in je eigen leiderschapskwaliteiten door middel van een zelf-test, en je bent in staat daarover schriftelijk te rapporteren.

4. Je ontwikkelt via wekelijkse opdrachten je eigen leiderschapsvaardigheden: Je leert zelf leiding te geven, je leert om te gaan met de valkuilen van besluitvorming, je leert om een charismatische speech te geven, en je leert om anderen te beïnvloeden - zelfs in een context van weerstand.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In elke organisatie, vereniging of club is leiderschap nodig om gezamenlijke doelen te kunnen bereiken. Maar wat is goed leiderschap? En welke kenmerken en vaardigheden maken iemand tot een goede leider? In deze cursus gaan we je een antwoord geven op de volgende vragen:

column2: Wat is leiderschap? En hoe belangrijk is leiderschap in de meeste organisaties?
Wat zijn de meest belangrijke theorieën van leiderschap in de wetenschap?
Wat weten we over goed versus slecht leiderschap?
Is er zoiets als vrouwelijk leiderschap, en waar moeten vrouwelijke leiders-in-spé rekening mee houden?
Ben ik zelf een leider, en welke vaardigheden moet ik ontwikkelen om een betere leider te worden?
Wat is het geheim van een charismatische speech?
Wat is macht, hoe krijg ik macht, en waarom is macht belangrijk?
In hoeverre beïnvloedt macht ons in ons denken en doen?

column1: Macht & Leiderschap onderscheid zich van traditioneel onderwijs op een aantal manieren.

Er zijn geen grote hoorcolleges maar kortere kennisclips met veel focus. We werken in kleine teams van 12 en zetten in op hoge kwaliteit-interacties tussen studenten en docenten. Er zijn wekelijkse opdrachten die worden beoordeeld met voldoende/onvoldoende. Toewijding aan het vak, je medestudenten, en jezelf zal ontzettend belangrijk zijn. Er is geen tentamen. Recidivisten doen volledig mee. Dit vak wordt beoordeeld met een voldoende / onvoldoende (niet met een cijfer). We maken geen gebruik meer van een boek als leidraad in de cursus. Dat scheelt zo’n 70 euro. In plaats daarvan vragen we je zo’n 40 Euro te reserveren voor diverse kosten.
Deze visie heeft zichzelf in 2020 bewezen als interactief, uitdagend, en effectief.

Je hebt één vast moment in de week waarop je present moet zijn voor je teamsessie. Sessies zijn normaliter op woensdagmiddag en vrijdagochtend. Wordt je ingedeeld op een moment dat niet uitkomt dan kun je ruilen via blackboard.

column1: Please note the prerequisites for this course at the bottom of the course description.

This course focuses on macroeconomic policy, specifically fiscal and monetary policy. The lectures focus on theoretical models in the literature underpinning these policies. A series of guest lectures by practitioners provides hands-on experience and two assignments (a presentation of state of the art literature and a simulation exercise) and a set of tutorials provides students with a good overview of the skills required of a macroeconomic policy maker.

First, we show how the policy recommendations of the IS-MP-AS-AD model familiar from the bachelor courses change when the economy is having balance sheet problems or is bound by the zero lower bound. After we have firmly established this model, we will explore the limits of this model by discussing debt sustainability issues and monetary policy credibility. After that, we introduce a small behavioural macromodel with heterogeneous expectations and show how the presence of animal spirits, i.e. waves of optimism and pessimism in the economy, change what prudent policies are. Finally, we briefly discuss bubbles, before we turn to the European debt crisis and the currency union in the last lecture.
At the end of the course the student is able to:
Explain on two levels (in plain English and using a model):
•           Effects of a shock on the macroeconomy
•           Goals of fiscal and monetary policy and their limitations
•           Effects of fiscal and monetary policy and their limitations
•           The tension between short-term and long-term policy goals
•           The role of expectations and behavioural biases in macroeconomics

column2: • Adequately summarize a key macroeconomic paper from the literature, describe its impact on the literature and explain whether and when it holds any relevance.
• Write code to generate an impulse response function and interpret it.

column1: The course comes with lectures, tutorials and guest lectures. The lecturer explains concepts and economic models, while tutorials are used to discuss exercises that help in understanding the models and concepts introduced in the lectures. The guest lectures are more practical and are given by experts in the field who are involved in making economic forecasts, evaluating election programs, preparing monetary policy decision, making economic news, etc.
As part of the course the student will do a simulation exercise and present a paper in pairs of two.
•           Final exam: 60% of the final grade (individual)
•           Simulation exercise: 20% of the final grade (group of 3)
•           Paper presentation: 20% of the final grade (group of 3)

The course is open to all students enrolled in the master program Economic Policy. For students from other programs, sufficient knowledge of macroeconomics (either a course in Advanced Macroeconomics or Finance) and econometrics (the Master course 'Empirical Economics' or another Advanced Econometrics course) is required.

In case online access is required for this course and you are unable (or do not want) to buy the access code, you are advised to contact the course coordinator for an alternative solution. <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After this course, the student will be able to

•          Describe and explain the interactions between the goods, money and labor market, the functioning of the economy in the short run, the relations between employment, inflation and output and the options for fiscal and monetary policy;
•          Describe and explain the factors of growth and the way in which they shape the long-run prospects of the economy;
•          Take a well-reasoned position regarding macroeconomic problems in general and in matters relating to economic policy in particular;
•          Comprehend the main arguments of the economic literature that is discussed in this course and critically assess their merits and limitations;
•          Comprehend the rationales of economic policy advisory organizations and central bank and be able to identify their merits and limits;
•          Comprehend basic statistical tools used to analyze economic issues;
•          Comprehend the position of an economic professional at the interface between economic science and economic policy.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course lays the foundations for analyzing the economy at the macro level by combining macroeconomics with issues of economic policy. The content is presented in such a way that the real-world problems (like unemployment and inflation) are placed at the central stage. Additionally, it builds on the economic thinking introduced in the micro course, by using concepts such as causality and models. The course starts with the the labour market and why economies face involuntary unemployment even when the economies are in equilibrium; and follows to the topics of variation in GDP and economic growth; the financial system; fiscal and monetary policies. The course ends with an economic analysis of three specific events: the great depression of 1929, the golden age and the recent financial crisis. The course presents theoretical models which explain labour supply, labour demand, and real-world problems as unemployment and wage-setting decisions. The course will pay special attention to monetary issues (such as money, inflation, and central bank’s policy) and fiscal issues (such as consumption spending and investment spending). The course will treat a few case-study material in order to illustrate the concepts and models presented before-hand. Students will be challenged to integrate the macroeconomics concepts and theories with insights from the other three PPE fields (Philosophy, Politics and History), and will use data to analyze a specific macroeconomic problem.</body>

column1: Relationship between assessment and learning goals:
Assessment forms are designed to simultaneously assess the above described learning goals. In particular:
1. The Midterm exam (25%) tests your mastery of concepts and their application to economic issues and policy questions, with respect to material covered during the first half of the semester

2.  The Final exam (30%) tests your mastery of concepts and their application to economic issues and policy questions of all material, with respect to material covered during the second half of the semester
3. The Macro Data brief (15%) tests your ability to collate, present and analyze key macroeconomic data in a given country
4. The Macro Policy brief (0%) tests your understanding of concepts and theories through application to and reflection about relevant contemporary policy issues

5. The Participation (10%) grade is based on class attendance, and participation in lecture and seminar discussions, which in turn are platforms for exhibiting your understanding of concepts covered and their application.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will be an in-depth exploration of ‘Macroeconomics’, which is the branch of economics that studies economic aggregates – in particular, over-all levels of prices, output, and employment in the economy. We will critically examine the historical and conceptual foundations of macroeconomics, including the ‘workhorse’ economics models that explain: the determination of output, employment, unemployment, interest rates, and inflation; the process of economic growth; the dynamics of international trade; and the workings of financial markets. As an intermediate course, emphasis will be given to developing in students both a strong grasp of technical foundations of the theory, and their links to and fit with real-world issues and policy questions of contemporary relevance. The course also fosters opportunities for actual engagement with relevant macroeconomic data.

The course program follows a textbook reference, and companion reading assignments to interrogate the material covered by the reference. Every week, a lecture is given pertaining to specific topic for the week. This is followed by a seminar in which ideas covered in the lectures are processed further and interrogated through discussion, assigned student presentations and small group learning activities.  The course program is divided into three parts. The first part covers the historical and conceptual foundations of macroeconomics; the second, macroeconomic theory and policy; and third, macroeconomic issues and applications.
Learning activities would include participatory lectures, weekly homework, and the completion of assignments involving macroeconomic economic data and policy analysis.

column1: At the end of the course you are able to:
·         Describe the macroeconomic principles that drive the economy in the short- medium and long run.
·         Describe the key concepts of macroeconomic theories.
·         Work with some basic models: the wage and price setting, the Phillips curve, the IS/LM-PC, and apply the effects of demand and supply shocks in the models.
·         Describe how economies fluctuate between booms and recessions.
·         Describe how governments and central banks can moderate costly fluctuations on employment and income.
·         Describe how the rate of unemployment and the level of output in the economy affect inflation.
·         Describe how long-term trends and differences in living standards and unemployment between countries are the result of technological progress, institutions, and policies.
·         Describe the economic lessons learned from the period of the great recession.
·         Think in terms of abstract models when discussing questions about the national and international economy.
·         Take a well-reasoned position regarding macroeconomic problems in general and in matters relating to economic policy in particular.
·         Handle simple macroeconomic models and the matching quantitative data (essential skill academic research).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Please note that this course specifically focusses at first years IEBE students. Students from other departments with an interest in macroeconomics are advised to select EC1PMA as that course will be better equipped for your position.

In this introductory course in macroeconomics we will teach you the insights of macroeconomic theory from a real-world perspective. We will combine chapters from the Blanchard text book and units from the text book The Economy to present a picture of contemporary macroeconomic problems and theories. Within the lecture and the tutorials we will structure the various chapters of Blanchard, units of The Economy and analyses of topical subjects into a coherent analysis.

The course will start with an introduction to key macroeconomic concepts, the use of models, the general equilibrium and emerging properties. The second session focuses on economic fluctuations and the importance of multiplier effects. The next step is to analyse the importance and effects of fiscal policy. To provide a tool for analysing the effects of policies we introduce the wage and price setting model and the Phillips curve. Special attention will be given to the origins of inflation and the difference between supply and demand shocks. Next to fiscal policy, we will give attention to monetary policy, after we’ve defined the role of the banking system in the economy. In order to understand the structure and functioning of a more traditional model, we will discuss the IS-LM-PC model and analyse the effects of fiscal and monetary policy in these models. In the long run the strength of institutions, the effects of creative destruction and inequality are essential elements to analyse. In the final session we will focus on the specific problems that are related to the Eurozone countries; fixed exchange rates, the (non)optimal currency area, sovereign debt problems and structural imbalances.
o   being able to give a brief oral presentation on a specific subject
o   being able to work with data software, such as Excel and Stata
o   thinking conceptually, thinking in terms of theory and capability to confront its predictions to real life
o   being able to execute the instructed research design,
o   being able to execute an instructed empirical research,
o   being able to apply theoretical concepts in research
o   Being able to work in a team for a well-designed task or project
Lectures once a week and tutorials two times a week
Development. This course builds on your basic knowledge acquired in Mathematics and Statistics and helps you develop essential basic skills in data management, statistics and presentation.

column1: In this course we will explore the role of multinational corporations in history. We will analyze the economic and social contribution of these big corporations to home and host countries, and compare them to the much larger number of small and medium-sized enterprises. We will also look for the damage the multinational corporations may have done to the world, through their careless handling of natural resources and the environment, their contribution to inequality by their activities in the Global South, the exploitation of workers, or their cornering of markets driving up prices to the disadvantage of global consumers. These are well-known criticisms, of course, but to what extent are they valid and how can these huge and powerful organizations contribute to solve the ecological and social challenges we face today?

column1: <body>This course provides an introduction to the study of economic history, by focusing on large debates that have been going on in recent years. These debates revolve around industrialization; globalization; demographic history; colonialism and their impact on long- term development, well-being, and inequality in different parts of the globe. Together these debates cover a timeline roughly from the 18th to the 21st century in a global context.</body>

discuss the outcomes of empirical research and link these with scientific theories;

indicate the relevance of his/her research for the field of Life Sciences and for society in general;
work effectively in a multidisciplinary team;
comprehensibly report research results orally and in writing, to an international audience of specialists and people from outside the field.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The major research project is an individual task. The project is build up from several elements: writing a  proposal, setting up and performing experiments and gathering emperical data, analyses including statistics, deriving discussion and conclusions based on data and literature research, writing a report, presenting data and findings in an oral presentation.
During the whole process the student is responsible for time management, cooperation within the research group and keeping the rules of scientific integrity.
Major research projects should take place within the UU, UMCU or an affiliated institute.
Prior approval of the Board of examiners is mandatory.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/228553,2023,Making Diversity Work: Building Inclusive Organizations,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. M. Vink', 'prof. dr. B. Derks', 'prof. dr. J.M. van der Toorn']",,"Course goals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon successfully completing this course, you are able to:

column2: • Recognize, reproduce and characterize the main concepts, theoretical approaches and empirical findings in the field of diversity and inclusion in organisations.
• Apply evidence-based insights to analyze concrete D&I policy and formulate possible improvements.
• Critically reflect on processes related to diversity and inclusion within the work teams in the course.

column1: Link between assessment tools and course objectives:

Objective 1 will be assessed in a multiple choice exam. The questions vary in level of difficulty and asses the degree to which students are able to recognize, reproduce the material (lectures and literature). Objective 2 is assessed in the work groups. In these work groups, individual and group assignments assess whether students are able to apply the material to concrete practical cases by analyzing the cases and formulating possible improvements. In addition, students’ ability to reflect on team processes related to diversity and inclusion (objective 3) is tested through self-assessment.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Today’s workplace is increasingly characterized by a diverse workforce. Diversity in demographics (e.g., age, gender, ethnicity) as well as in expertise, work styles, and skills can be highly beneficial for organisations. For example, diversity benefits creativity and innovation, which are essential to high performance in many work settings. However, many organisations fail to reap the benefits of diversity when they only focus on the numbers (hiring employees from diverse backgrounds) without working to build inclusive cultures. In this course, students will learn about the benefits as well as the challenges of building diverse and inclusive (D&I) organisations. The course is grounded in social and organisational psychology. In addition, students are introduced to a multidisciplinary approach on D&I (e.g., drawing on economics, law, gender studies, media studies, and sociology to name a few) to gain a multilevel understanding of how to promote D&I at the institutional level (e.g., which laws, organisational structures, AI systems promote or limit D&I?), the experiential level (e.g., why do people resist D&I policies? What is it like to not feel included at work?) and the symbolic level (e.g., how is power and status in organisations symbolised? How diverse is an organization’s board and why does that matter?). In work groups, students will analyze existing D&I initiatives and develop a theoretically sound and evidence-based approach to change these. Moreover, students will practice with effective ways to manage and stimulate D&I in their own work teams.

column1: After completing this course, students will have:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The implementation of public policy may well be the most important step of the policy cycle. Public policy becomes real only when implemented. It is when the state meets the street, that citizens experience the effects of governments’ awesome powers. How are great visions by politicians and policy makers in Paris, Brussels, or The Hague, eventually realised in Bruges, Aix-en-Provence, or Gouda? Service providers, such as the tax office, and individual public service employees, such as police officers, teachers, and nurses, eventually form the linking pin between public policy and citizens.

The ways in which governments and non-governmental organisations put their plans into practice determines their public value. And what looks great on paper, may end up totally different or even disastrous. Unintended consequences surface only when the machinery of government is set into motion. Similarly, bad policy may be compensated for by frontline workers’ relentless efforts. Yet, increasingly public services are provided by automated services and algorithms, with little human involvement.

In this course we will study the triangle of politics, public policy, and implementation. Our focus is on the wicked issues of making policy work in practice. The course provides an academic perspective on everyday government practice. We seek to analyse the promises and pitfalls of policy implementation.

We will read and discuss state-of-the-art literature on political-professional relationships, autonomous agencies, public management, and policy implementation theory and have a look at concrete real-life cases from around Europe and beyond.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - can translate research problems into data analysis problems
- can write comprehensive research reports on data-driven projects
- can critically evaluate data analysis approaches and execution
- have strengthened their core academic skills (writing, presenting, project organization) in the context of data analysis
- have a basic understanding of how computers work
- have been exposed to multiple digital tools
- have basic proficiency in multiple programming languages including Python, R, git and LaTeX
- can, in an automated fashion, manipulate large quantities of digital information by being able to search, sort, move, copy and concatenate files
- can clean, aggregate, subset, mutate, and visualise data and results, in an automated fashion
- can employ algorithmic approaches to problem solving
- will understand concepts of unstructured data and structured data, and can work with the commonly-used CSV and JSON data-interchange formats
- can work with common tools to acquire publicly available data and share their own data in a structured way

Many real-world problems and questions can be answered using data and automated data analysis tools. Increasingly, research in all disciplines, from the natural sciences to social sciences and humanities, involves big data. The availability of vast amounts of textual, audio-visual and structured data from digital sources is revolutionising research in the humanities and social sciences. The most advanced scholarship in these areas, currently and in the foreseeable future, relies on the use of sophisticated tools for accessing, processing, analysing and presenting this data.

In this three-week module, students are exposed to these principles and tools, in such a way that they can bootstrap their own further learning. Using real-world data, students gain familiarity and experience with some common approaches to handling large datasets. They learn how to think about and work with data in a sensible way, how to turn research problems into data problems, and how to communicate data problems and solutions effectively. This module also aims to demystify computers and programming, provide students the bootstraps to solve data problems using digital tools and programming languages, and to foster flexibility and self-learning. Students  engage with a number of very common programming languages and tools, culminating in a group project based on a real-world dataset, where they extract relevant information from it in an automated fashion, perform some simple analysis, and display the results visually.

As part of a liberal arts curriculum, this module stimulates the kind of thinking that our college hopes to engender: the use of multiple paradigms to solve problems, drawing on reasoning, logic, analysis, hypothesis testing, and formal problem-solving methods.

HUM/ SSC students: course counts as elective.
SCI: counts towards lab course requirement. Not recommended for Physics majors. Course does not count as a science course.

The scope of the module is a hands-on introduction to the tools and concepts of automated data analysis. As such, it covers the concepts of: operationalizing research questions; exploratory vs. confirmatory data analysis; iterative software development; designing data visualizations; using the right data structures; understanding file and data types; and troubleshooting / debugging. It introduces students to industry standard tools: R (including tidyverse and ggplot libraries), Python, LaTeX, system shells, and git.

As an introductory course, it does not cover: databases; app development; web development; maths; statistics; simulations; machine learning; experiment design and implementation; or any domain-specific research approaches.

This three-week module is full time, running from 09:00 until 17:00 each weekday. The first two weeks of the module consist of interactive instruction. The first week will focus on conceptual aspects of data-driven research, and the second week will focus on strengthening foundational programming skills in this context -- though theory and practical programming / data analysis will be mixed throughout the module. Each day will involve some combination of lectures, in-class exercises, group work, and classroom discussions. Additionally, on some days, the in-class work is to be handed in at the end of the day. These elements are evaluated, and make up the portfolio grades of week 1 and week 2. Generally, all work is expected to be completed during class hours, especially the graded elements -- little to no homework will be assigned.

During the third week, there is a focus on team-forming and project work. This week will include work sessions, presentations, and evening programs related to the theme of the module. The class, divided into groups of 3-4 students, will work on separate projects. At the start of the week, groups develop a written proposal for a data-driven research project. Throughout the week, they will execute this proposal, guided through regular progress meetings with the instructors in a format modeled on software development industry standards. At the end of the week, groups are brought together to a symposium where students will present their findings to the whole class. These presentations are not a graded element, and serve to communicate with the rest of the class, as well as obtain final feedback. After the presentations, groups finish writing up a final academic-style report on their project, which, together with the project proposal and the code implementation, forms the graded element of week 3.

All coursework in this module will be electronic, and students are requested to bring a laptop, with several gigabytes of free space -- when this is not possible, a solution will be found. All software tools, as well as any additional materials used in the course, will be open access or open source, and thus free of charge to students. Students will be pointed to a choice of tutorials and online courses, including the official tutorials given by makers of particular software, as well as simple user-friendly guides. Standard reference texts will be available during the module for students to consult for assignments. Whenever useful, lecture notes and programming cheat sheets will be provided. We will only be using software that is freely available. Detailed installation instructions will be provided at the start of the course.
This course is coordinated and taught by Teun van Gils, Lucie Kattenbroek, Joska de Langen and Joris Vincent.
Further information and course materials will be provided on our course website: www.ucudata.nl

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/230113,2023,Making modern science: a history of chemistry 1750-1950,English,Faculty of Science,,['prof. dr. A.P. Philipse', 'T. Hagendijk, MSc']",,"Course goals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. Student can account historically for the emergence of modern chemical concepts and theories  (such as oxidation, stoichiometry, organic chemistry, the table of the elements, osmotic pressure)
2. Student can characterize how chemistry has developed over the past two centuries, in terms of institutional settings, its relation to other disciplines, instrumentation, and social role.
3. Student can use historical examples to show that chemistry was never practiced in an ivory tower, but has always been closely connected to its societal context.
4. Student can connect developments in chemistry to broader developments in the natural sciences.
5. Student can use the history of chemistry to reflect on the nature of science, ranging from questions of scientific method to issues such as scientific integrity and social responsibility.

In terms of academic skills, this course focused on reading comprehension, academic writing, and reflection on the nature of science and the science social role from a historical perspective. These aims tie in closely with the learning objectives of the build-up of “Ethics, Philosophy and Society”, coordinated by Eelco Vogt.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: According to the standard narrative, modern science was born in the seventeenth century. This course, which focuses on the history of chemistry, argues instead that modern science emerged only in the past two centuries. The field of chemistry took shape around 1800 from a variety of practices, including natural history, natural philosophy, and pharmacy. It was around that time that Lavoisier introduced his oxygen theory of combustion. This period has been called the “Chemical Revolution”, but the term requires some qualification as there were significant continuities with the past and fundamental innovations were introduced only later in the nineteenth century, for example in the new, rapidly growing disciplines of organic chemistry and physical chemistry.

In this course we also pay a lot of attention to the institutional setting and changing social role of chemistry: from the rise of research (and teaching) laboratories to connections with industry and with war. Public perceptions of chemistry reflect chemistry’s central place in modern society and its discontents. Finally, in order to link the history of chemistry to broader developments in the history of the natural sciences – or the making of modern science – we shall frequently look at its shifting relation to neighboring disciplines.
The course is part of the leerlijn (build-up/trajectory/through-line) “Philosophy, Ethics, and Society” for chemistry students coordinated by Eelco Vogt.
The course can be followed as part of the minor History and Philosophy of Science: https://students.uu.nl/en/academics/minors/history-and-philosophy-of-science
The course can be used as preparation for the Master’s programme History and Philosophy of Science: https://www.uu.nl/masters/en/history-and-philosophy-science

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/231807,2023,Making, analyzing and interpreting observations",English,Faculty of Science,,"['prof. dr. ir. G.J.M. Velders', 'prof. dr. M.R. van den Broeke']",,"Course goals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. Is acquainted with basic data analyses techniques, calibration, data correction, outlier removal etc.
2. Is able to write programming codes (preferably in Python) to analyses observational data.
3. Is able to read modern scientific literature about topics in climate research.
4. Is able to describe analyze and interpret data.
5. Is able to present the results in an oral or poster presentation and written report in a clear and convincing manner.
6. Is able to design and implement a project workflow to study a geophysical problem using earth system data.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Observations are a key component in climate research. They are essential in process studies and the evaluation of numerical modelling.

In this course you will gain experience with in-situ measurements related to meteorological, cryospheric or oceanographic processes, and learn how they can help us to better understand the Earth system. You will apply statistical and machine learning techniques to interpret the data. You will be involved in setting up a meteorological measurement system in the Botanical gardens and analyze the data.</body>

In deze cursus wordt niet summatief getoetst. Individuele studenten krijgen, gevraagd en ongevraagd, formatieve feedback op hun ontwikkelingen ten aanzien van bovengenoemde leerdoelen.

column1: <body>Elke ouderejaars psychologiestudent krijgt vanuit de opleiding een tutor aangewezen. De tutor is docent in het studiepad waarvoor de student zich heeft ingeschreven. In de meeste gevallen is de studiepadcoördinator ook de tutor. Studenten die een andere docent dan de studiepadcoördinator als tutor hebben krijgen daarover bericht. De tutor volgt de studievoortgang en zal waar nodig actie ondernemen. De tutor helpt de student om zich thuis te voelen bij de opleiding, tot weloverwogen keuzes te komen, en zo het beste uit zichzelf en anderen te halen. Studenten kunnen zelf een afspraak met hun tutor maken. Vanuit de opleiding wordt er via de Blackboard-omgeving van de cursus 'Tutoraat Verdiepend' geïnformeerd over relevante onderwerpen: de naam van de tutor, voorlichtingen, evenementen en andere belangrijke zaken.</body>
