column1: Alle psychologiestudenten gaan na hun eerste jaar over naar een nieuw College en een nieuwe tutor.

Dit nieuwe Senior College heeft een verbredend en verdiepend karakter ten opzichte van zowel de studieloopbaan als de vakinhoudelijke stof. Het is de gemeenschap van studenten waar zij t/m hun derde jaar bij zullen horen en mee samen zullen werken bij het onderhouden van hun motivatie, exploreren van toekomstmogelijkheden, en voorbereiden op de arbeidsmarkt. Elk College komt minstens één maal per onderwijsblok bij elkaar. De studenten geven in overleg met hun tutor (en binnen de grenzen van de doelen van het tutoraat) zelf invulling aan het programma.

De tutor begeleidt de activiteiten van het Senior College en volgt de studievoortgang van de individuele studenten. De tutor helpt de studenten uit het College om zich thuis te voelen bij de opleiding, tot weloverwogen keuzes te komen, en zo het beste uit zichzelf en anderen te halen. De tutor nodigt elke student minstens één maal per jaar uit voor een individueel gesprek. Daarnaast kunnen studenten zelf ook afspraken met hun tutor maken.

Elk Senior College heeft een eigen Blackboard-pagina van waaruit de tutor en studenten van het College met elkaar kunnen communiceren. Daarnaast worden studenten via de Blackboard-omgeving van de cursus 'Tutoraat Verdiepend' vanuit de opleiding geïnformeerd over onderwerpen die relevant zijn voor iedereen: voorlichtingen, evenementen en andere belangrijke zaken.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/227599,2023,Mass Atrocities, Human Rights and Law",English,"Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Course goals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• the student will have gained an understanding of the various human rights responses under international law to mass atrocities committed in communities around the world (a field known as transitional justice).
• the student will have a critical understanding of the development of transitional justice and how it operates within the broader peace-building field.

• the student will have an understanding and knowledge about the historical development of transitional justice, the various justice processes that may be employed, and how they operate in theory as well as practice.
• the student will be able to identify societies in transition in contemporary settings and the applicable laws and legal processes.
• the student is able to understand and debate positions taken in key scholarship regarding transitional justice, including critical perspectives.
• the student is able to apply their knowledge about transitional justice processes to hypothetical cases.
• the student is able to present arguments from the perspective of different actors (i.e. states, NGOs, IGOs, civil society).
•  the student is able to identify, within specific contexts, challenges and potential solutions facing key stakeholders when developing processes to address past abuses.
• the student has developed the capabilities and skills to critically discuss and write about relevant topics in the field of transitional justice.
• the student will have developed knowledge of the law and how it operates in a political context, but also will have developed their written and oral advocacy and negotiation skills.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: How should a society deal with a history of serious violations of international human rights and humanitarian law? Should those believed to be responsible for violations face criminal prosecutions and sanctions? Or should a general amnesty be granted as a compromise in order to secure peace? Is it possible to prosecute thousands of perpetrators of widespread violence, and how should victims be remedied? Do victims deserve recognition and repair - and, if so, how? How does international law contribute to peacebuilding, reconciliation, justice, and reparation? These are some of the questions  addressed in this engaging and critical elective course.

Post-conflict peacebuilding refers to actions taken to support societies that are trying to avoid relapsing into conflict. It is a multi-dimensional endeavour with several pillars; one of which is referred to as transitional justice. Together with other pillars, such as security and rule of law, transitional justice is now firmly a part of peacebuilding responses. Transitional justice arose out of the need to address mass atrocities in societies in conflict. It is based on the idea that backward-looking processes, which acknowledge and address harms suffered, will help bring about more peaceful and stable societies. While there are debates about the definition, transitional justice is seen as “the full range of processes and mechanisms associated with a society’s attempts to come to terms with a legacy of large-scale past abuses, in order to ensure accountability, serve justice and achieve reconciliation” (UN SG report). These processes include domestic and international(ised) trials, truth commissions, reparation programs, vetting and lustration processes, and other efforts to promote reconciliation and memorialisation. These different justice processes have evolved over the past decades, and aim at (re-)establishing trust and the rule of law in societies transitioning from violence.

This course is designed for students interested in peacebuilding, rule of law, human rights, conceptions of justice, and international politics. The course includes foundational lectures on the theories, debates, and elements underpinning transitional justice, as well as on the various mechanisms. Students will be assessed via participation in class, written assignments, and a final exam. A highlight of the course is that in the small working groups, a hypothetical conflict is presented which students reflect upon over the course and attempt to negotiate transitional justice responses.

The course has three aims. First, that students will gain a critical understanding of the development of transitional justice and how it operates within the broader peacebuilding field. Second, that students will be able to apply this knowledge to hypothetical cases and will be able to present arguments from the perspective of different actors (i.e. states, NGOs, IGOs, civil society). Third, that students will develop the capabilities and skills to critically discuss and write about relevant topics in the field of transitional justice. In this sense, the course aims to develop not only students’ knowledge of the law, its application in practice, and also their written and oral advocacy skills. These goals are related to the scientific and social context around the field of transitional justice. Specifically, students will learn the various roles that law can play in dealing with past serious human rights violations and how law can help societies transition and, potentially, transform.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/229841,2023,Master Course Biophysics & Molecular Imaging,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. F.M. Berger', 'dr. H. van Ingen', 'prof. dr. A.M.J.J. Bonvin', 'prof. dr. F.G. Förster']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of the course, students should be able to:

i) reflect on the state-of-the-art and important recent developments within this filed of research; ii) discuss and critically assess literature from this field of research at academic level; iii) place this field of research in context of other research themes to promote interdisciplinary thinking.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Living matter at the molecular level is a seemingly chaotic, but nevertheless a tightly regulated soup composed of a myriad of different ingredients. To (start to) understand how these molecular ingredients create life we must determine their shapes and dynamics, visualize their distributions, and study the energies and forces that govern their interactions. These research concepts are at the basis of the MCLS track Biophysics and Molecular Imaging and the focus of this course.

The course covers key concepts and state-of-the-art research applications of biophysical techniques that allow imaging of molecules at the atomic level (NMR, X-ray diffraction, electron microscopy), as well as the dynamics of (single) molecules inside living cells (light microscopy and super-resolution microscopy), or determine the force required to detach two interacting molecules (single molecule force spectroscopy). The specific content of the course will vary somewhat from year to year.

Similar to other general track courses of the MCLS master, each day of the course is focused on a specific topic and may include lectures by principal investigators, short research lectures presented by PhD students or post-docs, or short technical lectures. In addition students will present and discuss research papers under supervision of one of the teachers and do one or two individual or group assignments.

Mandatory for students in Master’s programme: Mandatory for students in the track Biophysics & Molecular Imaging. MCLS students must follow at least 2 out of 4 general track courses, preferably 3 out of 4.
Optional for students in other Master’s programmes GS-LS:

YES. Interested students form other master programmes in and outside the GS-LS should contact the course coordinator before enrolling. But only when maximal capacity for this course (50) is not reached.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/229465,2023,Master Course Genes to Organisms,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. A.F.J.M. van den Ackerveken', 'dr. ing. M. van Zanten', 'dr. M. Boxem', 'dr. M.C.G. Proveniers', 'dr. R.A. Ohm', 'prof. dr. R. Pierik', 'prof. dr. S.J.L. van den Heuvel']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of the course, students should:
i) Understand how genes, RNA, protein and metabolites function in an organized and coordinated manner in cells, tissues, and ultimately, the entire organism.
ii) understand how diverse biological processes, e.g. development, immunity, and responses to the environment, are studied both at the molecular level as well as at the level of the whole organism.

iii) be acquinted with the theory behind methods that are used to identify genes, study transcripts and proteins, and determine the function of genes in model organisms, from bacteria and fungi, to plants and Metazoan animals (C. elegans).
At the end of the course, students should be able to:
i) translate fundamental scientific knowledge to applications in Medicine, Plant Breeding, and Biotechnology.

ii) reflect on the state-of-the-art and important recent developments within this field of research; discuss and critically assess literature from this field of research at academic level; place this field of research in context of other research themes to promote interdisciplinary thinking.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

How life functions at the level of tissues and whole organisms, and how organisms respond and adapt to environmental conditions is the main topic of the Genes to Organisms track that is introduced in this general course.
Students will be introduced to the research topics that are covered in this track and will learn about state-of-the-art methods used in genetics/genomics and analysis of gene function.
Experts in these field will introduce state-of-the-art genetic, genomic, bioinformatic, molecular biological,  and physiologic techniques.

Similar to other general track courses of the MCLS master, each day of the course is focussed on a specific topic and may include lectures by principal investigators, research seminars, or technical lectures. In addition students will present and discuss research papers under supervision of one of the teachers and do one individual and one group assignments
Course manual/material will be available through Blackboard.
Mandatory for students in Master’s programme: Mandatory for students in the track. MCLS students need to follow at least 2 out of 4 general track courses, preferably 3 out of 4.
Optional for students in other Master’s programmes GS-LS:

YES. Interested students form other master programmes in and outside the GS-LS should contact the course coordinator before enrolling. But only when maximal capacity for this course (50) is not reached.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/229543,2023,Master Course Molecules & Cells,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. P.M.P. van Bergen en Henegouwen', 'prof. dr. A.S. Akhmanova', 'prof. dr. J.A. Killian', 'prof. dr. S.G.D. Rudiger']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of the course, students should have:

i) profound understanding of several key principles in cell biology and biochemistry relevant for this track. ii) understanding of how these principles are applied to the state-of-the-art research done within this track; iii) insight into optimal combinations of molecular and cell biology techniques necessary to advance a particular field (e.g. intracellular trafficking or protein folding).
At the end of the course, students should be able to:

i) reflect on the state-of-the-art in the fields of biochemistry and molecular cell biology and on important recent developments in these fields; ii) discuss and critically assess literature from this field of research at an academic level; iii) place this field of research in context of other research themes to promote interdisciplinary thinking.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Understanding how molecules function in a cellular context is the basis for understanding life. In this course, we will focus on several research topics, in which exciting advances have been made in the recent years. We will discuss how established  and emerging research methodologies make it possible to advance the textbook knowledge on the mechanisms underlying the function of biomolecules such as proteins and lipids within living cells. The research concepts discussed in the course are at the basis of the MCLS track Molecules & Cells.

Specific topics will be introduced by experts, who will also discuss different advanced techniques ranging  from live cell and single molecule imaging and biophysical and biochemical analysis of proteins and lipids to  structural biology approaches such as Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR).

Similar to other general track courses of the MCLS master, each day of the course is focussed on a specific topic and may include lectures by principal investigators, short research lectures presented by PhD students or post-docs, or short technical lectures. In addition, students will present and discuss research papers under the supervision of one of the teachers and carry out one or two individual or group assignments.
Course materials (lectures and research papers used during the course) will be available through Blackboard.
Mandatory for students in Master’s programme: Mandatory for students in the track. MCLS students need to follow at least 2 out of 4 general track courses, preferably 3 out of 4.
Optional for students in other Master’s programmes GS-LS:

YES. But only when maximal capacity for this course (50) is not reached. Interested students from other master programmes in and outside the GS-LS should contact the course coordinator before enrolling.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The objectives of the Mater Earth Sciences Talks are:

column2: • to train students in conveying the outcomes of scientific research to a broader audience of peer students,  academics and other stakeholders.
• to get acquainted with the breadth of scientific research within the Departments of Earth Sciences and Physical geography
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: For graduation in one of the Earth Sciences master programmes, each student must attend at least 10 scientific presentations / symposia / seminars offered by the Departments of Earth Sciences and Physical Geography, and their research groups and give a poster presentation of their own MSc Research project during one of the dedicated poster sessions of Earth Sciences Utrecht. A portfolio should be compiled, which consists of short, written reports about at least 10 talks you have attended (see for contents of the reports the example in the portfolio template file below) as well as an A4 copy of your poster and a short summary of the peer-feedback received on your poster (see below) and a short reflection on this feedback.

During each academic year, three poster sessions will be organised by the team of programme leaders. These sessions will be held on an afternoon and will be followed by drinks. Students will be asked to display and present your poster during a poster session (i.e., stand by your poster and discuss your research with session attendees). Furthermore, all poster presenters will be asked to peer review three other posters. The dates and locations of the poster sessions as well as guidelines for printing, putting up your poster and providing peer feedback will be communicated at least one month before via an email announcement via the Master earth Sciences talks Blackboard community.

It is your responsibility to maintain a portfolio of the reports of each (i.e. at least 10) attended presentation and the report on the peer-feedback on your poster. Write a short report about every talk you have attended as well a a copy of your poster and a short reflection of the peer feedback you received on your poster. A template of the portfolio can be found in the Master Earth Sciences community on Blackboard.

Eligible presentations for inclusion in your portfolio can be found in the calendar on Blackboard (see left menu) and include MSc-thesis talks/colloquia, FEST (Friday Earth Science talks), lunch lectures, and other occasional talks or seminars. Apart from talks offered by the Departments of Earth Sciences and Physical Geography, part of the portfolio may consist of reports of talks given elsewhere, such as presentations given at other UU research groups (for example, IMAU-colloquia), public lectures (inauguration or farewell speeches, Studium Generale), national and international symposia, seminars or conference sessions, as long as there is a clear and relevant link to Earth Sciences. Note that a symposium counts as 1 event/ Earth Science talk. The same applies to conference sessions. If you attend several talks during a symposium, you can either select one for you report or you write a summary of the whole symposium. Not more than one session per conference is allowed to be included in your portfolio. Reports of business presentations and workshops, and lectures as part of a course do not count towards the portfolio.

After finalising the portfolio, please submit it via the link below. After evaluation, your portfolio will be marked as “passed” in OSIRIS within 10 working days after submission during the regular teaching period (i.e. week 36 – 51 and week 2 – 28). Please take this term of 10 days into account when planning your graduation date.
Please submit your portfolio using the link in the Blackboard community, The portfolio will be checked for plagiarism.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/229883,2023,Master Level Computational Biology,Dutch, English",Faculty of Science,,['prof. dr. P. Hogeweg'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing the module the student is able to:

column2: • knows how computational models of dynamical systems can be used to investigate biological processes. (e.g.topics mentioned in 3).
In particular;• the need of computational models• how to formulate computational models• how to analyze computational models• how to interpret results of computational models
• knows implicit assumptions of various model formalisms.
In particular:• ODE and PDE.• FSM and CA• event based models (e.g. Gillespie)• individual (particle) based models• evolutionary models
• knows basic theory derived from computational modeling of• network dynamics (e.g. cell cycle, cell differentiation).

In particular:• spatial pattern formation (e.g. spiral and chaotic waves)• multilevel evolution (genome evolution, eco-evolutionary dynamics)• multilevel morphogenesis (from genes, to cells to tissues to organism)

• able to understand current literature using modeling. In particular• extracting the bottom line• evaluating the explicit and implicit assumptions of the models• relating the discussion to the theoretical knowledge gained in 3

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During the course, the emphasis will be on composing and analysing exact models based on specific hypotheses. The results of the analyses offer an understanding of the original biological system. The models studied address fundamental questions from a variety of biological fields, including:
- eco-evolutionary dynamics and spatial pattern formation
- genome evolution (e.g. interaction between gene regulation and evolution)
- morphogenesis and mechanical interactions between cells
A number of different model formalisms are used, namely:

column2: • knows how computational models of dynamical systems can be used to investigate biological processes. (e.g.  topics mentioned in 3). In particular;
• how to interpret results of computational models
• knows  implicit assumptions of various model formalisms. In particular:
• knows  basic theory derived from computational modeling of
• network dynamics (e.g. cell cycle, cell differentiation). In particular:
• spatial pattern formation (e.g. spiral and chaotic waves)
• multilevel morphogenesis (from genes, to cells to tissues to organism)
• able to understand current literature using modeling. In particular
• evaluating the explicit and implicit assumptions of the models
• relating the discussion to the theoretical knowledge gained in 3.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/228543,2023,Master Mentoring Program Interdisciplinary Social Sciences,Dutch, English",Faculty of Social Sciences,,[],,"Course goals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Students and Student Mentors pro-actively take responsibility to getting the maximum benefit from their studies by closely collaborating together with fellow students and teaching staff; by developing themselves personally and professionally; by addressing challenges in a critical but professional manner and by making use of the various coaching and social activities that the Mentoring Program offers. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: All students participating in the ISS Masters Programs will automatically enroll in the Master Mentoring Program, including at least the following services and activities:

- Bonding with fellow students & becoming part of UU's academic community through small group meetings; social and educational activities as organized by the student mentors & regular group meetings or coffee corners in which students can exchange their ideas, suggestions and experiences with the teaching staff.

- During office hours, through confidential (private) conversations and through e-mail students can at any time share their study-related, course-related or personal challenges in a confidential setting with their Mentor, who may refer them to for example the study advisor or student psychologist if needed.

- From each Masters Program at least 2 student mentors will be recruited. They will be offered a part-time student job at Utrecht University. They are responsible for communicating and reporting/documenting commonly asked questions; suggestions; ideas and challenges that fellow students come up with during the academic year. They will communicate this to the coordinator(s) of the Master Mentoring Program and to the teaching staff of the related courses.They draft constructive proposals and thereby contribute to guaranteeing the quality of the Masters education. They are also responsible for creating a positive group feel and stimulating collaboration, for example by bringing together teachers and students through organizing 'coffee corners' and by regularly organizing social or educational group activities for their fellow students.
- Workshops & seminars in collaboration with the 'academic professional' courses.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/230635,2023,Master Project: Internship,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. M. Peeters'],,Course goals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. Understand when and how disciplinary knowledge affects youth practices, identify (different) needs of stakeholders and connect different perspectives when working as a youth professional.
2. Process and provide feedback in a constructive manner while reflecting on your own and others’ academic and professional development.
3. Communicate in a respectful, ethical and appropriate way with peers and professionals.
4. Demonstrate flexibility in thinking and acting, deal with uncertainty, pose critical questions and be creative and innovative in the development of solutions.
5. Think, communicate and act as an academic professional by taking ethical and academic principles into account while working as a youth professional.
6. Evaluate and analyze an intervention or policy in relation to a particular youth challenge.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The student will complete an internship at a relevant organization in the professional field of youth (e.g. Trimbos Institute, Dutch Youth Institute, local and national government organizations such as Health and Youthcare Inspectorate, Defence for Children, World Health Organization). During the internship the student conducts activities for the internship organization on the level of an academic professional, and under supervision of a certified* academic professional at the internship organization. A practical internship can also encompass research activities (for and in collaboration with the internship organization).

Students work together in project/intervision groups. This way of working aims to encourage discussion on experiences during the internship and on personal and academic goals as set in the portfolio. The students meet in groups to learn from each other and provide/receive feedback on the progress of their internship and reflect on particular internship experiences (e.g. the experienced tension between academic standards of working and the reality of working as an academic professional, the role of interdisciplinarity in practice). It is expected of students that they attend and prepare all project meetings properly. Alternative assignments will be required for missed meetings.

Students will reflect on this progress, the provided/received feedback as well as on the identified academic and personal learning goals in an individual internship report which will part of their portfolio.
*certified is having completed an academic master and at least 1 year working experience.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/230634,2023,Master Project: Thesis,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,[],,Course goals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
Formulate concrete (research) questions and write a comprehensive literature review on a topic in the field of youth
Apply methodological and analytical skills to analyze the data and to write a sound methods, results and discussion section of a scientific paper
Communicate your research in an accessible manner to different audiences, orally and in writing
Assess academic work of colleagues and provide academically sound constructive feedback taking various (stakeholder) perspectives and disciplines into account
Reflect on the ethical and interdisciplinary aspects of your own and others’ research, and the application of your research findings in practice
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Master thesis represents the final stage of the Youth Development and Social Change (YDSC) academic Master's program. You can choose one of the following two options:

1. Combining your practical internship (in an external organization or in one of our research departments) with your thesis, using either existing or newly collected (qualitative or quantitative) data from your internship organization or research department

2. Separating your practical internship (in an external organization or in one of our research departments) from your thesis, using existing (qualitative or quantitative) data for your thesis via your thesis supervisor

In all cases, the student will write a thesis on a social issue related to a theme in the domain of Youth Studies. Students will work together in project groups of up to six students who all have chosen the same overarching theme and are supervised by the same supervisor. The student will independently and individually conduct research aiming to answer a scientifically and/or practically relevant research question using existing or newly collected quantitative or qualitative data (see section on data below). In the Master thesis, the student demonstrates their interdisciplinary knowledge and skills by critically reflecting on their own and others’ (inter)disciplinary approaches in theories and or/methods that are applied. The Master thesis should have the form of a scientific journal article and is always an individual product. However, during the process of thesis writing students in the project group will be asked to provide peer feedback and critically review each other’s work.

The Master thesis consists of the following individual end-products that will be evaluated by the thesis supervisor: (1) the thesis in the format of a scientific journal article, (2) a presentation of the thesis and how your findings can be applied in practice.

It is only possible to make use of (newly collected) data from the internship organization if these are high-quality data that the student can use to answer their research question(s). Students wishing to use data from the internship organization (or from another external institution) must submit a written request (two weeks before the start of the course) that includes a description of the research data to the supervising lecturer and course coordinators of the Master thesis and internship that includes a description of the data to be used.

Format: Students work together in project groups of up to six students. This way of working aims to encourage discussion when developing the master thesis design; to accompany the substantive exchange of theoretical findings and research results; to maintain contact between students, and to help the students finish their projects on time. Project group meetings will be organized to give students the opportunity to discuss the progress of their thesis with their supervisor and fellow students.

<body>At the end of the first part of the research project, the student:

column2: • knows the goals of the research project; this includes a translation of a problem in the field of catalysis, colloid science or nanophotonics into a relevant research question;
• has obtained first results and has analyzed them;
• is able to discuss these first results, in spoken and written English, including the underlying knowledge and background to a target group;

column1: The assessment results in a pass, fail or repair.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>The student will perform the entire research group in one of the Debye Research groups.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/229847,2023,Master Research Scheikunde,English,Faculty of Science,,['prof. dr. A. Meijerink'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After the end of the research project the student has learned to:
1. execute the research designed in part 1 under the supervision of a member of the scientific staff according to the rules of good scientific practice and ethics;
2. design a suitable research plan according to international scientific standards;
3. discuss the outcomes of the acquired materials and/or data and link them to scientific theories;
4. handle, analyse and interpret original derived data/results in a correct manner;
5. apply an appropriate set of experimental techniques;
6. to evaluate his/her own learning and development process and to adjust this process if necessary;
7. demonstrate a professional working attitude (able to solve tasks by him/herself);
8. to work independently and take initiatives where necessary;
9. indicate the relevance of his/her research in the field of nanomaterials science and to reflect critically upon his/her own contribution;
10. work effectively in a multidisciplinary team and participate critically and constructively in the scientific debate in the research group;
11. to discuss, in spoken and written English, the results of research, including the underlying knowledge and background, to a target group composed of specialists or non-specialists

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of the research project (37,5 EC), the student has learned to:

column2: • can apply an appropriate set of experimental or computational techniques
• can handle, analyse and interpret data in a correct manner and link them to scientific theories
• is able to evaluate his/her own learning and development process and to adjust this process if necessary
• demonstrates a professional working attitude (able to solve tasks by him/herself)
• performs research under limited supervision and take initiatives where necessary
• is able to indicate the relevance of his/her research in the field of nanomaterials science and to reflect critically upon his/her own contribution
• is able to work effectively in a multidisciplinary team and participate critically and constructively in the scientific debate in the research group
• is able to discuss, in spoken and written English, the complete and final results of research, including the underlying knowledge and background, to a target group

column1: In addition the honours degree the student has learned to (either one of the following two options of 7,5 EC):

column2: • writing of a PhD proposal of a topic to be freely chosen by the honours student. This proposal is eligible to compete in the Debye Graduate Programme.

• writing a research paper as a first author for an international peer-reviewed journal using the results of the master research project or the internship project, ready up to the level of submission.

column1: <body>The thesis should be the product of independent research. The thesis should demonstrate that the students are able to produce new scholarly knowledge and insight and can share this insight with others, in a manner that meets international academic standards.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: A thesis is a scholarly text in which the students are expected to contribute, on the basis of independent research, to a debate within the field of theatre, dance and performance studies. It should be structured around a central research question or aim (set out in the introductory sections) to which it provides an answer (set out in the conclusion).

The students are expected to formulate a central research question or aim at the beginning and demonstrate its relevance in relation to scholarly discussions on the topic. The body of the thesis includes an account of how the students approached and operationalized the research and a presentation and analysis of the research findings. In the conclusion, the students analyze the findings in light of the original research question, discuss the broader implications of these results, and offer recommendations for future research on the topic.

The MA Thesis preferably is written during block 3. In case of alternative internship schedules, this course can be followed in combination with the MA Internship throughout block 3 and 4 (lint option).</body>

column1: Can identify a topic on which a distinctive and significant contribute can be made to the philosophical research literature.
Can develop a sustained and cogent piece of written work, in response to constructive criticism at all stages of the project.
Follows established norms of bibliographic documentation that reflects a thorough understanding of standards of academic integrity.
Can articulately defend the conclusions and arguments of the thesis in an oral examination (viva).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The RMA thesis is a scholarly text in which you are expected to contribute, on the basis of independent research, to a debate within your discipline. It should be structured around a central research question (set out in the introductory sections) to which it provides an answer (set out in the conclusion).

The central research question, to be determined in consultation with your thesis supervisor, should be clearly formulated at the beginning and its relevance to scholarly discussions within the discipline set out. The body of the text should explicate and defend your approach, your findings, and your overall argument in favor of your central claims. In your conclusion you should analyze your findings in the light of your original question and explain the broader implications of your conclusions.
The thesis should be written in correct and clear English. It will normally be 16.000 to 32.000 words long and may not exceed 40.000 words (including notes and bibliography).

The final version of the thesis is due at the end of the 9th week of block 4.  An oral examination of the thesis (the “viva”) will be held approximately two weeks later, involving the student and a committee of three examiners.
As part of the thesis writing process, students participate in two workshops in which their plans for the thesis and a draft of a chapter are discussed.
More information is available in the RMA Philosophy Thesis Handbook, via Blackboard.

column1: 1. you should have acquired theoretical and empirical knowledge on your research topic.
2. you should be able to individually formulate, develop, organise, and conduct empirical research, and to analyse data with suitable methods.
3. you should be able to apply this knowledge, skills and attitudes on ‘real-life’ situations, and reflect upon them.
4. you should have acquired cross-cultural competences.

5. you should be able to present your research plans and findings in varied ways (oral and written) for different audiences (student peers, lecturers, host/partner organisations, local communities etc.).</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Master thesis/Internship course is designed to give you an opportunity to conduct a substantial, independent and fieldwork-based research on a chosen topic related to  international development. You are expected to execute the research plan drafted during the Advanced Methods & Techniques course and where possible engage in knowledge co-creation with partners. You will collect / search for data, analyse data, and present the research in a thesis at the end of the period. Before that, you will also present in-between findings in three products: 1) an interim report 2) an oral presentation and 3) a communication product. You will work under the supervision of a staff member at IDS, where possible in collaboration with a partner organisation.
Research contains original fieldwork and empirical data collection / analysis, e.g.:

column2: • On-site fieldwork research: interviews, surveys, (participant) observation, participatory methods, spatial methods, etc.
• Digital / remote data collection, e.g. online surveys, digital interviews, collaborating with local students elsewhere (under certain conditions)
• As additional method, not main method: analysis of secondary data e.g. statistical datasets, literature review, policy documents, media, social media ‘big data’

column1: Research topics should be related to global flows of capital, people, ideas etc. and their implications for people/human development (see Development Themes).
Drawing on their research findings, students write their MSc thesis. Most of the teaching concerns individual supervision; some extra workshops are also provided.

For those of you who have just started their thesis or research the University Library offers short (2-hour) guided search sessions. These will give you a head start in finding information. Staff will ensure that you do not miss out on any new important databases with journal articles and other information sources. For information and registration go to: http://www.uu.nl/university/library/en/disciplines/geo/courses/searchsessions/Pages/default.aspx</body>

• work together in a team with diverse backgrounds, towards a common goal
• can work together on a research team (e.g., in a hierarchical team of supervisor and junior member(s), together with peers or as a trainee in a company's research team or unit)
• present the solution in a written report, which is concise but still contains the most important insights

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Please note: the information in the course manual is binding.

The Master’s thesis aims at training students to perform research independently and to specialise in becoming a change agent that helps businesses to realise the transition to more sustainable business models. All SBI degree qualifications must be addressed (see section 1.3 in the course manual.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Master’s thesis is a research project in which the student will learn to conduct independent research, applying new or existing methods to a problem, relevant to a corporate sustainability and/or sustainable innovation related problem. Depending on their ambition and interests, students focus on one of these research themes and develop their own research question, with support from their university supervisor.

The research may take place in an organisation other than the university (it is not compulsory), depending on the data needed to answer the research question. In general, a wide range of firms and institutions are possible locations to perform your project, including those in other countries. The first step, however, is to select a research theme and the concomitant supervisor at the University.

The student will work under the guidance of a supervisor at the place of internship, and will have regular meetings with the university supervisor to discuss updates of achieved progress in the form of written concept-versions of the final report.

The student is expected to show ample initiative to realise the goals of the defined research. This includes collecting and analysing relevant scientific and other literature, approaching specialists or other relevant persons for additional information or assistance on research related methods and skills, making timely and regular appointments with the internship supervisor and university supervisor.
Learning-by-doing is part of the project. The student is encouraged to attend meetings or conferences etc. that are relevant to the research work.

Besides presenting your own internship research, all students are obliged to attend at least 10 other presentations. At least 6 presentations should be thesis presentations by students from your own Master’s programme. The other 4 presentations may be attended at other programmes (Sustainable Development, Innovation Sciences, Water Science & Management, Energy Science, or other relevant Master’s programmes), or at presentations by IEES  staff members or Copernicus lectures.

column1: Please note: the information in the course manual is binding.
On competing the course students are able to:

column2: • Design and conduct independently and systematically an academic research project at the Master level in the field of Human Geography by applying academic research and discussion skills;
• Formulate a consistent, academically and societally relevant research objective and research question by analyzing recent international literature and debates;
• Select and apply appropriate research techniques for the gathering and analysis of research data;
• Give written and verbal reports on the results of the research project;
• Reflect on both the research methods used and the research results achieved;
• Make relevant (policy) recommendations based on the analysis.

column1: <body>The Master's thesis is a piece of individual work. Each student selects a topic, from a list of given topics, with a matching supervisor. (It is possible several students work on similar projects under the same supervisor, allowing some scale economies, but the grading is always individual.) Students who want to come up with their own thesis subject, possibly with an associated internship, should contact the coordinator by the end of period 1.

column1: While working on the master's thesis, the student will gain experience with setting up, executing and reporting an (applied) scientific experiment in cognitive psychology or related field. The research can be proposed by one of the supervisors at the university or by a research facility outside the university. Based on a relevant problem or question from the occupational field or theoretical exploration, hypotheses will be developed, and methods to test these hypotheses will be decided upon. The results, conclusions and possible recommendations following from the study will be presented in an academic paper.

To discuss possible options and procedures students should contact the thesis coordinator of the programme. It is a prerequisite that the thesis coordinator approves the research the student wishes to study. It is strongly advised to the student to start his/her search for a topic and/or institute of interest in a timely fashion. For more information, the student can contact the thesis coordinators Jeroen Benjamins (J.S.Benjamins@uu.nl) and Stella Donker (S.F.Donker@uu.nl).

column2: • Writing a scientific report (whether or not tailored to the occupational field)
• Academic thinking and acting as an (applied) researcher

column1: <body>After finishing the master's thesis the student has gained experience with conducting psychological empirical research. At the end of this course, the student will be able to:

column2: • formulate testable hypotheses based on scientific arguments
• design or modify a study to test the hypotheses
• collect data autonomously or with others; develop materials if needed
• write a clear and structured report according to the APA guidelines
• collaborate with other team members in research projects
• reflect on ethical issues during all phases of the research process
• review and evaluate scientific empirical research based on scientific arguments

column1: During the master's thesis psychology students will gain experience with almost every aspect of scientific research. With the research proposal it is tested whether students can prepare a scientific study design and write a concise study proposal. Evaluation of the practical work (e.g., testing participants, analyzing) and presenting the study will be part of the final grade. The most important part of the master's thesis is the research report (format: scientific article). Hence, in the grading, the thesis, the presentation and the process will be considered, covering the whole of academic research and communication skills and knowledge.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The topic of the master’s thesis has to be a quantitative empirical investigation within the domain of developmental psychology and needs to be linked to a theoretical framework. Most theses are conducted in the context of on-going research projects in the department. These projects focus on themes in the fields of normal as well as problematic development of children and adolescents in different social contexts (home, school, peer group). Research for the thesis may also be conducted outside of the university. In such cases sometimes supervision can be supplied by the organization where the research is performed, but always a member of departmental staff (CCAP) must be involved too: either as first or as second supervisor. Moreover, grading has to be done by teachers involved in the CCAP master program. Please see the course manual for regulations and procedures.

The primary product and basis of grading of the master's thesis is the thesis itself. In principle, it should be written in English, but exceptions are considered, if based on good grounds. Second, the student needs to contribute to a symposium where all students present and defend their findings in English (no exceptions). A third criterion for grading concerns the research process, which will be monitored by the supervisor across the whole course of the research project.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Conducting or participating in an empirical, scientific study is one of the essential elements of the master curriculum. The master thesis is the ultimate test of being capable of planning, conducting and reporting such a study.

Participation in a research project with the aim of writing a master thesis can start either at the beginning of the first or at the beginning of the second semester. Announcements for potential projects become available on a special Blackboard site well in advance of the starting points and students are invited to apply for a project well in advance of the official start. The announced projects are often studies proposed by teaching staff from the department, but sometimes external projects are open for student participation too. Under strict conditions, students can conduct a self-designed study. In that case, the student needs to contact the thesis coordinator well in advance (at least ten weeks) before the official start of the thesis course. Only if the thesis coordinator accepts the proposal on the criteria of scientific quality and viability (often after feedback and revision), can self-designed research projects be conducted.

Thesis studies can be conducted alone or in small teams (usually couples). It must be emphasized that - despite the group work - the thesis itself is an individual product. All students working on their thesis meet regularly in small groups for intervision. In these intervision sessions, progress and problems are discussed, best practices and tips are shared, and feedback is given on each other’s written work. Next to intervision sessions, supervision is provided on a regular basis by the thesis supervisor.

The master thesis needs to be written according to the general structure of reports of empirical psychological studies (introduction, methods, results and discussion) and hypotheses need to be tested using quantitative research methods. Additional use of qualitative techniques and methods is allowed. A public oral presentation of the research findings is mandatory.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/228466,2023,Master's Thesis Neuropsychology,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['A.F. ten Brink, MSc', 'dr. A. Keizer', 'dr. C. Ruis', 'dr. M.J.E. van Zandvoort', 'dr. N. van der Stoep', 'dr. T.C.W. Nijboer', 'prof. dr. A. Postma', 'prof. dr. H.C. Dijkerman', 'prof. dr. S. van der Stigchel']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After finishing the master's thesis the student has gained experience with conducting neuropsychological empirical research.

During the master's thesis neuropsychology students will gain experience with almost every aspect of scientific research. With the research proposal it is tested whether students can prepare a scientific study design and write a concise study proposal. Evaluation of the practical work (e.g. testing participants, programming, analysing) and of the final presentation of the results of the study will be a part of the final grade. The most important part of the master's thesis is the research report (format: scientific article).</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Neuropsychology is concerned with the relation between the brain and behaviour. A major aspect of neuropsychological research involves developing and testing models of the human brain and its many functions, such as memory, language, perception, motor control, attention, emotion and intelligence. Another important domain entails determining the consequences of neurological or psychiatric disorders for cognitive functioning and developing methods of treatment.

The student will develop and carry out neuropsychological research as well as report it as part of the Neuropsychology thesis. Research methods may involve assessment of patients, experimental research with healthy individuals and literature based research such as meta-analyses. The precise format of the research for the thesis will be decided upon in consultation with the supervisor. Below is a list of examples of topics (listed for each member of staff) that are available for thesis research:
Prof. dr. A. Postma: spatial cognition, memory
Prof. dr. C. Dijkerman: visual and tactile perception, motor control, body representations
Dr. M. van Zandvoort: cognitive disorders after CVA and other neurological deficits, cognitive rehabilitation
Dr. S. van der Stigchel: visual perception and attention, visual deficits after brain damage, eye movements
Dr. T. Nijboer: multisensory integration, (cross-modal) attention, synesthesia, hemispatial neglect, (cognitive) rehabilitation
Dr. Nathan van der Stoep: multisensory integration, perception in 3-D space, crossmodal spatial attention, sensory recalibration, hearing loss, rehabilitation
Other topics at Utrecht University or external institutes can be found on Blackboard.

To discuss thesis topic and procedures, students should contact the coordinator of the programme. It is a prerequisite that a supervisor from the department as well as the departmental coordinator approve the topic the student wishes to study.

After completion of the thesis the student is able to independently conduct simple (neuro)psychological research. In addition, the student will have acquired basic skills to write a scientific report in a format that is commonly used in the field.
Communication skills: Interpret, report and communicate findings of a neuropsychological study
Organisational skills: Planning a project, scheduling and testing participants
Academic skills: Critically evaluating, analysing and structuring information
Academic abilities: Analysing and evaluating research reports, generating falsifiable hypotheses
Preparing and conducting research: Collecting and analysing data, reporting results of a study
Professional skills: Academic thinking and working as a neuropsychologist, being able to use scientific research methods in the context of neuropsychological research</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Writing a master's thesis is the primary objective of the second year of the research master programme.
The entire course will be taught in English. This also includes assignments and exams.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The master's thesis is written under individual supervision by at least one of the senior researchers within the Department of Psychology who are involved in SHP. In addition, guidance in planning and conducting the master's thesis project and in preparing the master's thesis is provided on a regular basis in the courses SHP11 and SHP12. The SHP thesis should be an example of good theoretically grounded and methodologically sound research, either original or as part of an already existing research project within the research programs participating in SHP.

The master's thesis should have the form and format of a publishable research article of about 6000 words (including references and excluding tables and figures). This however may vary depending upon the requirements of the intended journal for publication. Note: When a master's thesis project requires complex data collection, it must be kept in mind that such data collection is time consuming. The time schedules for those master's thesis projects that do comprise complex data collection should clearly indicate the time budget needed for data collection and should clearly indicate that and how data collection fits into the total available time budget for the project.</body>

column1: Health Psychology is concerned with the study of psychological and behavioral processes in health, illness, and health care, but its basic premises can also be applied to alternative behaviors, for example in the field of education, sustainability, and finance. In order to improve health and health-related behaviors it is important to learn in detail about the processes and strategies enabling people to increase control over their own behavior, which is addressed in this field of study. Different strategies and possibilities to change health-related behaviors are addressed, as well as their theoretical rational that explains the working mechanism. This way, students will be provided with a sound understanding of the theoretical and empirical basis of health promotion, and they will be equipped with the conceptual and practical skills to understand, design, and evaluate health promotion policies and interventions. The subject of the master's thesis has to be within the specific field of one of the supervisors and should be linked to a current project of the department. Current research topics in the department include, for instance:
To discuss thesis topics and procedures, students should contact the coordinator of the master track Health Promotion, Catharine Evers, PhD. Dr. She can be contacted via: c.evers@uu.nl.

In the thesis the student learns to function independently as a researcher in the domain of Social Psychology. The thesis involves a literature-based, empirical, quantitative study, resulting in a witten report that includes both scientific and practical implications. The subject of the master’s thesis typically falls within the expertise of the supervisor. Topics of interest include the role of attitudes, norms and other factors in explaining behaviour, the influence of habits and automaticity of behaviour, effectiveness of persuasive communication and other behaviour change strategies, the (dys)functioning of close relationships, person perception and social interaction, understanding social justice and its consequences, and morality and normative behaviour. The thesis covers every stage of the research cycle: formulation of the problem and hypotheses, in-depth theoretical study, design of the study and materials, data collection, data analysis, and reporting (oral and written). After completion of the thesis, the student is able to independently conduct simple psychological research. In addition, the student will have acquired basic skills to write (and present) a scientific report in a format that is commonly used in the field.

The following aspects will be assessed: theoretical insight, research skills, work attitude, quality of oral presentation, quality of the thesis report. The assessment of the quality of the report covers formulation of the problem, in-depth theoretical study, design of the study, data collection, data analysis, and reporting. A specification of the assessment criteria can be found in the guidelines on Blackboard.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The domain of social psychology is concerned with the functioning of people in social situations. This social functioning is studied on different levels: the individual, the interpersonal, and the group or organisation. The research that is performed within the department is fundamental as well as applied, and involves both experimental and field research methods. The topics under study as well as the theoretical perspectives are broad, but all emphasise the importance of social influence and social-cognitive processes. The subject of the master's thesis has to be within the specific field of one of the supervisors and should be linked to a current project of the department. Topics of interest include (amongst others):

column2: • norms and other factors in explaining social behavior
• the influence of habits and automaticity of behavior
• effectiveness of persuasive communication and other behaviour change strategies

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the Master thesis is that you demonstrates that you possess the ability to:

1. design, with partial guidance by a thesis supervisor, a 15 EC research project by formulating, analysing and evaluating issues and problems within the field of new media and digital culture, and setting up a research concept that adheres to the guidelines of the Master’s program;
2. carry out largely independent research on the topic described in the approved research concept;
3. report, in the form of the thesis itself, about this research at a level that complies with generally accepted disciplinary norms.
After completing this course, the student will have:

- the ability to employ relevant theoretical concepts for an analysis of contemporary and/or historical new media objects/phenomena, situated within (a subset of) their cultural, social, and political-economical contexts;
- thorough knowledge of relevant scholarly new media debates;
- the ability to differentiate, apply, and reflect upon the use of relevant methods to answer research questions pertaining to new media objects/phenomena.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Various (PhD) researchers are invited into the course, which adds to insight and knowledge of current developments in the workfield.

The MA thesis is a scholarly text in which you are expected to contribute, on the basis of independent research, to a debate within the field of new media and digital culture. It should be structured around a central research question which is clearly formulated in the introductory chapter and has a strong relevance to active scholarly discussions. The body of the text should show the methodology you employed to answer this question, the theoretical considerations you have made, and what your findings were. In your conclusion you should analyze your findings in light of your research question and explain the broader implications of your conclusions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The MA Thesis is a scholarly work that adds to the academic debate on new media and digital culture; as such, it showcases the student's ability to (largely) independently report on research findings, a professional skill that is highly valued within the working field.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Writing a master's thesis is the major objective of the second year of the MERM program. The master thesis should have the form of a scientific journal article that is in principle publishable.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The criteria for the evaluation of the master's thesis are: a) scientific contribution: clear research question, convincing argumentation that the study adds to the scientific literature; b) Theory: use of theory, clear hypotheses, relevant literature; c) Method: correct data collection/handling, measures, choice and description of method of analysis; d) Results: correct interpretation of findings, clear presentation; e) Discussion and conclusions: summary, broader implications, limitations, future research; f) Written presentation: writing, structure, tables and figures, references; g) Work independence: degree of independence; amount of supervision required; time management. The Master's thesis is written under individual supervision by a MERM teacher.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/228186,2023,Master's thesis,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['prof. dr. M. Dekovic'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: After finishing the thesis, the students are able to:
• identify a coherent set of research questions and hypotheses, embedded in theory and current literature;
• understand ethical norms in conducting research, analyzing and storing the data and reporting;
• design a method to examine research questions;
• analyze the data by using appropriate statistical tools;
• draw conclusions based on the results, link own findings to the broader literature, and identify limitations of own work;
• write a scientific report in the form of a journal article
• give a short informative presentation on their research project
In the final product (MA thesis) all the above aims should be realized.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Writing a master's thesis is a major objective of the second year of the DaSCA program. The Master’s thesis is the critical and final test of this program. It is written in the form of a research article for an international scholarly journal, and is supervised by staff members who are senior fellows in the various research programs participating in the DaSCA. The thesis is defended during the Thesis Defence at the end of the second year.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/228204,2023,Master's thesis,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['T.A.J.M. van Gog'],,Course goals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The master thesis is embedded in previous research and literature on the chosen topic and includes a theoretical elaboration of the research problem, followed by an empirical test of some implications of the theory and a discussion of results and conclusions. The thesis has the form of a publishable research paper and thus includes: (1) an introduction in which a theoretical framework is formulated and relevant empirical research is integrated, concluded by a set of hypotheses; (2) a method section with a description of the sample, procedure, design, analyses, and measurement instruments; (3) a results section in which the data are analysed and the hypotheses are tested; (4) a discussion that summarises the main conclusions and describes their theoretical and practical implications. The topic of the thesis should preferably be integrated in the ongoing research programmes of EdSci research groups. The decision on the topic for a thesis is taken at the end of the first year in the programme. The preparation of the thesis and the research proposal starts in the second semester of the first year, supported by the Integrative Practical (EdSci08) in which the problem formulation, relevant theories and hypotheses are discussed with fellow students and lecturer(s). In the second year, the thesis process is supported by the Research seminar (EdSci12A and 12B), in which the proposal and the methods, analyses, results, and interpretation are likewise discussed.
- The ability to write a research paper / research article</body>

<body>The master thesis contributes to the knowledge base of the community of academic educational professionals.  The aim of writing the master thesis is to enhance the application of knowledge and understanding in the field of educational science and methods/statistics, as well as enhancing skills regarding judgements, communication, and learning skills. </body>

column1: <body>The master thesis is the final result of the academic master Educational Sciences. It should contribute to the collective knowledge base of the community of educational professionals. The master thesis is the result of an empirical research project as described in the master thesis plan. The master thesis is written in English.  Thematic groups will be formed with several supervisors and peers. There will be regular meetings of these theme groups, during which students will receive feedback from their supervisor and peers on their thesis. The audience for the master thesis is the community of educational scientists and practitioners. This means that the thesis should have a broader applicability and generalisation than the results of an internship project. The master thesis will be admitted in the digital thesis library and will be publicly available. Furthermore, the thesis will be presented to and discussed in an audience of educational professionals, scientists, and practitioners during a conference.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Conducting rigorous analysis of a social problem by applying social science theory:

column5: Conducting professional policy research and producing reports
Formulating policy advice based on rigor policy research
Developing tools and skills in the field of policy research and building a network within the professional world of policy research

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Together, the internship and labour-market orientation (course code 201600012) and the Master's thesis (201600013) form a whole and are worth a total of 30 credits. They each have a workload of 15 credits.

Students carry out policy research (preferably of a quantitative nature) into a social or societal problem, which is related to the chosen track (or a combination of track courses) from the Master's programme in Contemporary Social Problems. This problem can be one that plays out in Dutch society in general or one that is relevant to a specific sector or organisation. A thorough problem analysis of the social or societal problem forms the start of the graduation research project, in which it is essential to apply socio-scientific knowledge. From this follows the further set-up and drafting of a Master's thesis.
The research project can take a variety of forms. Examples include:
•      a socio-scientific research project, which produces new, policy-relevant knowledge and which demonstrably clarifies a social problem;
•      a policy evaluation that looks at the impact a policy measure has or has had;
•      a literature review of a social problem which, with the help of expert interviews, results in a realistic policy design;
•      a research project looking into the functioning of organisations and institutions with a focus on the course and implementation of policy processes.

Based on the research carried out, each Master's thesis will pay attention to policy advice. In their policy advice, students will take into account social and political issues (implementational validity) and the actual implementation of the advice.

In principle, the internship and policy research will take place in combination. This can only be waived in exceptional cases. Agreement about the policy research to be undertaken will take place at the beginning of the internship and a suitable supervisor will be assigned. A project plan and a strict timetable will be discussed with the assigned supervisor.

A Master's seminar will run parallel to the policy research at which students will present their progress and results to a forum of students and lecturers. In conclusion, a presentation of the Master's thesis will take place in the form of a mini conference. Testing of the thesis will be carried out by two assessors, one of which was not involved in the supervision of the thesis.

column1: The Master’s thesis is a research project in which the student will learn to conduct research independently in the field of energy and materials, whereby new methods are developed and/or applied or existing methods are applied to a new problem. The research should be relevant from both a scientific point of view (it should expand the body of scientific knowledge) and a societal point of view (it should produce knowledge that can contribute to a better understanding or the solution of societal problems in the area of energy).

column2: • Master’s thesis proposal. The proposal should be handed in within four weeks after starting the Master’s thesis. In this proposal the student should be able to translate a research question into a research plan that includes a justification of the problem, research question(s), methodology to be used, expected results and a time plan. The proposal should be approved by the supervisor before submission to the Board of Examiners.
• Thesis. The Master’s thesis is written in English. The student is encouraged to write the thesis in the form of a scientific article that is suitable for publication in a refereed journal.

• Oral presentation. The purpose is to elaborate on the project for a scientific audience. The student should be able to extract key insights and lessons from the research work and present them to an audience of peers in an adequate manner
