column1: After completing this course students are able to:

column2: • identify parallels between the current and historical developments

column1: The final course grade, on top of participation, is based on five elements: three written assignments, a written in-class exam, and a research paper
1.     Written assignment 1 (a short essay arguing if, from a historical perspective, today's economy is or is not in crisis): test your ability to interpret historical events
2.     Written assignment 2 (outline the international  'journey' of a chosen product from the assembly of resources to consumer's hands): helps you understand the concept of globalization
3.     Written assignment 3 (your research in a graph): helps you formulate a sound scientific research question
4.     Written in-class exam: tests your ability to identify parallels between the current and historical developments, as well as, interpret historical events from different perspectives
5.     Research paper: tests your ability to use relevant methodologies and theories, formulate a sound scientific research question, and independently write a paper

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This course aims to give students an overview of long-term developments in the world economy and teach them how the theoretical insights of social scientists help us to understand world history better. The main emphasis lies not so much on the chronology of events, but on understanding the two main problems of social and economic history: what are the origins and drivers of economic growth, and why does that process result in wide disparities in wealth?

Additionally, this course intends to teach students to independently carry out a research project. Students will acquire general skills (e.g. developing a research project) as well as skills specific to social and economic historians (e.g. source criticism, working with data and theory). It prepares them for working at the MA level.

Class meets twice a week in two-hour sessions. During the first part of the course, we will analyze the globalizing world from its nineteenth-century roots until today, using Frieden’s already classic textbook Global Capitalism. Research articles will be used to deepen our insight into particular events and to familiarize ourselves with techniques and methods. The second part of the course will build on the latter. Students will set up and conduct their own research project. They will learn how to develop their research question, how to identify and apply the relevant theory, and how to locate and use the necessary empirical data. Besides close supervision, feedback by fellow students is a key component of this part of the course.

column1: De volgende doelen worden met deze cursus nagestreefd:
•    De cursus geeft alle eerstejaarsstudenten van de faculteit Sociale Wetenschappen de mogelijkheid kennis te maken met honours onderwijs.

•    Studenten krijgen inzicht in de toegevoegde waarde van het Honours College Sociale Wetenschappen in aanvulling op het reguliere programma. Hierbij horen elementen als: wat is de toegevoegde waarde van een multidisciplinaire blik op sociaalwetenschappelijke problemen? Hoe is sociaalwetenschappelijke kennis gerelateerd aan andere processen in de maatschappij? Wat zijn andere manieren om in het honoursprogramma reguliere kennis te verbreden of te verdiepen?
•    Studenten doen op een aantal algemeen sociaalwetenschappelijke thema’s verbredende en/of verdiepende kennis op.
•    Studenten krijgen vanaf het begin van hun opleiding de mogelijkheid honoursactiviteiten te ontplooien naast het reguliere programma.
•    Studenten kunnen aan het eind van het eerste jaar een gefundeerde keuze maken of ze het hele Honours College Sociale Wetenschappen willen volgen.
•    Studenten werken samen met studenten uit andere disciplines.
•    Studenten maken kennis met ouderejaars honoursstudenten en de activiteiten van deze studenten.
•    Studenten maken kennis met docenten van het Honours College.
•    Studenten ontwikkelen een multi- en/of interdisciplinaire blik.
•    Studenten leren hun honoursprogramma deels zelf in te richten en keuzes te maken.
•    Studenten leren delen van hun onderwijs zelf vorm te geven.
•    Studenten leren professionele leerdoelen te formuleren en erop te reflecteren
•    Studenten werken aan een aantal specifieke academische vaardigheden (column schrijven, poster maken en presenteren, debatteren, pitch geven)

Door middel van opdrachten en bijeenkomsten wordt kennis verdiept en/of verbreed en interesses worden geëxploreerd. De uitwerking van deze opdrachten die diverse professionele vaardigheden toetsen (verslagen, reflectie en column schrijven; poster maken en presenteren; debatteren; pitchen) wordt van feedback voorzien en beoordeeld met voldaan/niet voldaan.

In elk seminar staat een onderdeel van het Honoursprogramma centraal. Actieve voorbereiding en deelname wordt verwacht van de studenten. De community bijeenkomsten worden georganiseerd door oudere jaars FSW Honours studenten en hebben als doel kennis te maken met de community en de elementen van het Honours College (Community Day, Create Your Own Course, het Debat en de Honours Parade). Bij Create Your Own Course volgen studenten een mini-cursus dat is ontwikkeld door oudere jaars Honours studenten. Als studenten aan het einde van de cursus zich willen aanmelden voor het FSW Honours College, zetten zij hun cursusproducten in een portfolio en beschrijven zij hun leerdoelen voor tijdens het Honours College.

column1: In de cursus wordt een aantal academische vaardigheden geoefend aan de hand van een biomedisch onderwerp. De student zoekt geschikte en goede informatie bij een biomedisch onderwerp naar keuze en bereidt een literatuurreview, een krantenartikel en een presentatie voor. Het literatuurreview wordt samen met een medestudent geschreven in het Engels en is bedoeld voor medestudenten. Het individueel geschreven artikel is bedoeld voor de wetenschapsbijlage van ‘de Volkskrant’. Het Engelstalige review wordt voorgelegd aan medestudenten en voorzien van opbouwende kritiek en suggesties. Na het verwerken van deze opmerkingen wordt de tweede versie van het review ook door de docent voorzien van feedback. Het krantenartikel wordt alleen door de docent voorzien van commentaar. Met behulp van de commentaren van de medestudenten en/of docent worden beide producten verwerkt tot een finale versie die aan het einde van de cursus moet worden ingeleverd. Daarnaast bereidt elke groep een presentatie (Engelstalig of Nederlandstalig naar keuze) over het review voor. In het review en het krantenartikel worden, waar mogelijk, ook ethische en maatschappelijke aspecten van het onderwerp meegenomen.
De cursus heeft een maximale capaciteit van 14 studenten.
De cursus kan worden gevolgd door eerstejaarsstudenten van de volgende opleidingen: Biomedische Wetenschappen, Biologie en Farmacie.
Na afloop van de cursus heeft de student:

column2: • inzicht gekregen in het zoeken en verzamelen van geschikte literatuur;
• geoefend met het helder formuleren van een probleemstelling;
• een Nederlandstalig krantenartikel en een Engelstalig literatuurreview geschreven;
• opbouwende en zinvolle kritiek gegeven op het review van anderen;
• opbouwende kritiek op correcte wijze verwerkt in eigen werk (krantenartikel en Engelstalig review);
• samen met een andere student een presentatie gegeven aan medestudenten;
• een maatschappijkritische en ethische reflectie gegeven op een biomedisch onderwerp.

column1: Interactieve hoorcolleges/werkcolleges, feedbackgesprekken met de docent, artikelen lezen, het schrijven van een Nederlandstalig artikel (individueel) en een Engelstalig literatuurreview (twee studenten), feedback geven en een presentatie voorbereiden en geven. De totale contacttijd voor dit blok bedraagt ongeveer 10%.

Toetsing van de cursus gebeurt door beoordeling van het Nederlandstalige artikel, het Engelstalige literatuurreview, het peer-review rapport, de presentaties en de maatschappijkritische en ethische reflectie. Alle opdrachten moeten worden ingeleverd en tenminste met een 5,0 worden beoordeeld. De cursus wordt afgesloten met een voldoende als het eindcijfer van alle opdrachten gemiddeld tenminste een 5,5 is.

column4: Doelstelling en inhoud

In de cursus OZM verdiepen we ons in de zorg in Nederland op drie verschillende niveaus: micro-, meso-, en macroniveau. Zorg draait om mensen en daarom verdiepen we ons aan de hand van een persona (fictieve patiënt/burger) in deze drie niveaus. Met welke vormen van zorg komt iemand in de thuissituatie in aanraking, welk zorgverleners zijn betrokken en hoe ervaart iemand zijn/haar gezondheid (microniveau), hoe is de zorg op een hoger niveau (op het niveau van de zorginstelling) georganiseerd en wat merken de patiënt en de zorgverlener hiervan (mesoniveau)? En hoe is de zorg op overheidsniveau georganiseerd? Denk aan beleid vanuit het ministerie van VWS of een gemeente en aan bekostiging van zorg. En wat kunnen we leren over zorg als we kijken naar groepen patiënten en burgers (populatieperspectief): wat zijn risicofactoren voor ziekte en wat betekent het populatieperspectief voor de toekomst van zorg (macroniveau)? Dit blok heeft als doel inzicht te geven in de zorg en het zorgsysteem waarin je als professional straks komt te werken.

Je verdiept je steeds drie dagen in de zorg voor jouw persona per zorgniveau (3 dagen micro-, 3 dagen meso- en 3 dagen macroniveau). Dit doe je aan de hand van colleges, opdrachten, werkgroepen, e-modules, podcasts, documentaires, artikelen en interviews met zorgprofessionals in meet-the-expertsessies. Een deel van de opdrachten voer je samen met een groepsgenoot uit, deze vormen tezamen je eindverslag. De persona’s worden verdeeld in de eerste werkgroep op dag 1. In de laatste werkgroep vertel je je groepsgenoten wat je geleerd hebt over jouw persona en de doelgroep waartoe deze behoort. Zo doe je kennis op over diverse patiëntengroepen.
Dit blok vindt plaats in week 44 en 45 van het kalenderjaar (eind oktober en begin november). Enkele voorbereidende onderwijsonderdelen vinden plaats in de weken voorafgaand hieraan.
-   Leerboek Volksgezondheid en Gezondheidszorg, – Stronks en Burdorf - 9de druk, online via UU bibliotheek
- Mediatheek met (wetenschappelijke) artikelen, podcasts, webinars, documentaires op Blackboard

De student maakt individuele opdrachten en schrijft met een medestudent een verslag. Beide onderdelen moeten voldoende zijn om een voldoende eindbeoordeling te kunnen halen. Zie het blokboek Oriëntatie op Zorg en Maatschappij voor details van de toetsing.
Contactpersoon en informatie: mw. A.W. Kersten via secretariaat: OrientatieZorgMaatschappij@umcutrecht.nl

column1: PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS COURSE IS TAUGHT IN EINDHOVEN.
Period (from – till): Quartile 2, Time slot D (We 5-8, Tu 9-10, We 1-4), 13 November 2023 - 04 February 2024
Responsible lecturer: dr. C.C. van Donkelaar; co-lecturer: prof. K. Ito

With every activity we undertake, there is motion in our joints while they are heavily loaded. In our bodies there are three kinds of joints: synovial, cartilaginous and fibrous. In the former two, a unique type of tissue, cartilage, helps us to overcome this adverse and mechanically challenging environment. In synovial joints, i.e. fluid filled joints, a thin layer of articular cartilage covers the bones and provides an almost frictionless bearing surface. In cartilaginous joints, a complex structure of fibrocartilage provides less mobility but is able to transmit high loads between the bone ends. This course addresses questions such as: how does healthy cartilage deal with these mechanically challenging conditions? What is the interplay between the biomechanics and biology in these tissues? What happens when cartilage damage occurs? What are the most common diseases affecting cartilage? What are current possibilities and challenges in treating joint degeneration?
Will be distributed during the course.
Please register at the TU/e, course code: 8TM10 at least 4 weeks before the start of the course. Osiris registration will be done retroactively when results from the TU/e are received.
Mandatory for students in own Master’s programme:
Optional for students in other GSLS Master’s programme:
Basic biomechanics, Basic cell and molecular biology, Basic tissue anatomy and morphology.

column1: Brieven, vonnissen, slavernijregisters: archieven bevatten schatten aan onuitgegeven handgeschreven teksten. In de cursus Paleografie 16e en 17e eeuw leer je Nederlandstalige handgeschreven bronnenmateriaal uit de vroegmoderne tijd lezen en transcriberen. We bestuderen de bronnen daarbij rond een centraal thema: de vrijheid van meningsuiting. Door het kunnen lezen en leesbaar maken van deze bronnen krijg je toegang tot verborgen geschiedenissen die hierover fascinerende vragen en inzichten opleveren. Ontdek de rijkdom van saillante Utrechtse beledigingszaken, geboekstaafde ruzies in de scheepsjournalen van Admiraal de Ruijter en de ‘vergiftigde pen’ van een Leidse student.

column1: Aan het einde van deze cursus beheers je de vaardigheden om Nederlandstalige handschriften uit de vroegmoderne tijd te kunnen lezen en zelfstandig archiefonderzoek te doen naar deze periode

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Brieven, vonnissen, slavernijregisters: archieven bevatten schatten aan onuitgegeven handgeschreven teksten. In de cursus Paleografie 16e en 17e eeuw leer je Nederlandstalige handgeschreven bronnenmateriaal uit de vroegmoderne tijd lezen en transcriberen. We bestuderen de bronnen daarbij rond een centraal thema: de vrijheid van meningsuiting. Door het kunnen lezen en leesbaar maken van deze bronnen krijg je toegang tot verborgen geschiedenissen die hierover fascinerende vragen en inzichten opleveren. Ontdek de rijkdom van saillante Utrechtse beledigingszaken, geboekstaafde ruzies in de scheepsjournalen van Admiraal de Ruijter en de ‘vergiftigde pen’ van een Leidse student.
-in samenwerking met het Utrechts Archief en het Brabants Historisch Informatiecentrum
-oefenen met een online tool, speciaal voor UU-studenten
-digital humanities: kennismaken met de nieuwste methodes
-gastcolleges over onderzoeksprojecten als Language Dynamics in the Dutch Golden Age
-onmisbaar voor literatuur-, rechts- kunst- en cultuurhistorici, sociaal-economisch historici en historische taalkundigen

column1: <body>This course offers insight in the regulation of metabolism and its dysregulation in various endocrine diseases. Other related subjects are nutrition and the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal axis.  </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The first topic discussed will be the metabolism of carbohydrates, fat and proteins. Next, students will examine the supply of nutrients through foodstuffs and the processing of vitamins and minerals. They will then examine the energy balance in detail. Endocrine diseases are often characterised by a shortage or surplus of hormones. This imbalance then often leads to a clearly defined pathology that may involve more than one organs. The endocrine organs dealt with in this course include the pituitary, the hypophysis, the adrenal glands, the thyroid, the parathyroid glands and the pancreas.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Studenten verwerven in deze cursus kennis van:

column2: • De plaats van de sociale wetenschappen tussen natuurwetenschappen en geesteswetenschappen
• Dilemma's en debatten in de sociale wetenschappen m.b.t. de relatie tussen wetenschap en praktijk
• Historische voorbeelden van interdisciplines en theorieën over de verwevenheid van individu, cultuur en maatschappij

column1: Studenten verwerven in deze cursus vaardigheden om:

column2: • Op academisch niveau te schrijven over actuele debatten in de sociale wetenschappen.

column1: Paper: beoordeling niveau academisch schrijven en toepassing wetenschapsfilosofische en wetenschapshistorische kennis
Tentamen: beoordeling kennis (inter)disciplinariteit, relatie wetenschap-praktijk, geschiedenis en filosofie van de sociale wetenschappen

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In de cursus worden drie met elkaar samenhangende hoofdonderwerpen behandeld: (a) de dynamiek van disciplinevorming en interdisciplinariteit,  (b) het ontstaan en de ontwikkeling van de sociale wetenschappen tussen natuurwetenschappen en geesteswetenschappen en (c) de wisselwerking tussen wetenschap (theorie en onderzoek) en praktijk (beleid en interventies).

In het proces van disciplinevorming kunnen verschillende fasen worden onderscheiden. Na eerste, verspreide aanzetten tot de definitie van een vakgebied, treedt een proces van institutionalisering op waarin het object en de grenzen van een discipline worden vastgelegd. In dit proces (maar ook daarna) spelen wetenschappelijke en maatschappelijke legitimering een belangrijke rol. Deze oefenen op disciplines vaak een trekkracht in verschillende richtingen uit, in het bijzonder als wetenschap wordt gelijkgesteld met natuurwetenschap en de praktijk om contextgebonden analyses van sociale vraagstukken vraagt.  Aan de hand van historische voorbeelden worden de dilemma's waarvoor de mens- en maatschappijwetenschappen hierbij gesteld worden systematisch behandeld. Tevens wordt aandacht besteed aan de overeenkomsten en verschillen in de ontwikkeling van menswetenschappen en maatschappijwetenschappen.

We gaan in deze cursus in op hoe institutionalisering van disciplines mogelijkheden creëert, maar ook grenzen. In het bijzonder als ze zich bezighouden met de verwevenheid van individu, cultuur en maatschappij zijn sociale wetenschappers geneigd disciplinegrenzen te overschrijden, bijvoorbeeld in de vorm van interdisciplines, die voortkomen uit onvrede met de beperkingen van disciplinaire kaders (bijvoorbeeld cultuurpsychologie als belichaming van de twijfel aan universele psychologische wetmatigheden).

De analyse van actuele debatten, zoals over evidence based policy of over de manier hoe welzijn op een rechtvaardige manier kan worden verdeeld, vormt de tweede invalshoek in deze cursus. Er wordt systematisch ingegaan op de wetenschapsfilosofische en argumentatieve kaders van deze debatten, waarbij de student uitgenodigd wordt zelf stelling te nemen.

<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na in het vak Commerciële contracten in te zijn gegaan op de verschillende contracten die vennootschappen sluiten ten behoeve van hun bedrijfsvoering, wordt in het vak Overnames & Commerciële procedures nader ingegaan op de verschillende overeenkomsten uit de overnamepraktijk.

Het is vaak onvermijdelijk dat een vennootschap tijdens diens levensloop ofwel andere bedrijven overneemt ofwel zelf overgenomen wordt. Welke overeenkomsten worden er gebruikt in een overnameproces en welke elementen, van ondernemingsrechtelijke, arbeidsrechtelijke en mededingingsrechtelijke aard, mogen niet ontbreken in een overnamecontract? Ook kan er behoefte bestaan aan toetreding van extra investeerders. Wat zijn de juridische mogelijkheden daartoe? Deze onderwerpen staan centraal in het vak Overnames & Commerciële procedures dat in periode 2 wordt verzorgd. Daarbij komen zowel  allerlei aspecten rondom het openbaar bod op aandelen in een beursgenoteerde vennootschap (public M&A) als onderhandse overnames (private M&A) aan de orde. Bijzondere aandacht is er in dit verband voor familievennootschappen. Verder gaan we in op de overwegingen om al dan niet ‘naar de beurs’ te gaan en hoe een dergelijke beursgang juridisch in zijn werk gaat. Ook komen aspecten van het concernrecht, joint ventures en het jaarrekeningenrecht naar voren in dit vak. Daarnaast wordt tevens ingegaan op diverse commerciële procedures, zoals de mogelijkheid voor aandeelhouders om afgeleide schade te verhalen en de zogenaamde massaschadeprocedures (zoals de WCAM en de WAMCA) waarmee vennootschappen steeds vaker worden geconfronteerd.
Plaats van de cursus in het curriculum:

column1: In the Core Seminar 1, the development of professional skills focuses on paper writing, literature research, presentation skills, and giving and responding to feedback.
The aims of the Core Seminar 1 are as follows:
1. to acquire an advanced understanding of the philosophical topic chosen for the year, with special emphasis on integrating distinct philosophical perspectives;
2. to improve one’s skills in writing a philosophical paper, including the stages of research and revision;
3. to improve one’s skills in presenting research results in a symposium setting and responding to questions from the audience;
4. to draw on what has been learned in the course in engaging with current philosophical research projects;

5. to reflect on and improve one’s participation in seminar discussions, in providing feedback on the work of other students, and in presenting course readings to the class in a way that deepens other students understanding of the texts and generates a good seminar discussion.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Core Seminars are semester-long course that combine an in-depth investigation of a philosophical topic with training in key skills and interaction with researchers from ongoing research projects. Staff from two different areas of philosophy co-teach the seminar on a topic that draws on their overlapping research interests, but from distinct approaches. At various points in the semester, researchers form the department will present ongoing research and engage with students on connection with the seminar’s theme.
In the Core Seminar 1, the development of professional skills focuses on paper writing, literature research, presentation skills, and giving and responding to feedback.
The topic for 2021-2022: Human Nature and Human Action

We are rational animals; we are political animals, Aristotle used to say. Two very famous definitions, apparently simple if not banal. As a matter of fact, the source of many problems, as a close reading of the Nicomachean Ethics suffices to prove. What does it mean that we are rational? What does reason stand for? We think, we know, we talk … and we act: what is the relation between reason and action? These are some of the questions we are going to address in our course by combining an historical and a theoretical approach. We will focus on a close reading of Aristotle and Hannah Arendt, together with recent philosophical debates on practical reasoning and its limits. More specifically, once we have clarified the problem of reason (the Greek logos, a word with many meanings), we will proceed along two lines, by tackling two major problems, the relation between knowledge and action (Aristotle, Anscombe, Ford, Fernandez), and the opposition between creation and production on the one side and action on the other (Aristotle, Arendt, Ryle, Schuringa). In the first part, we will discuss both Aristotle's and neo-Aristotelian accounts of the capacity for practical reasoning, and also pay attention to the question how this capacity can misfire. In the second part, we will discuss Arendt's views on work, action and judgement, and discuss critical recent responses to her ideas.

Part of the seminar is also dedicated to the development of professional research skills. Among other things, we will take a closer look at literature research, oral presentations, giving and responding to feedback and writing an academic paper.

column1: The aims of the Core Seminar 2 are as follows:

1. to acquire an advanced understanding of the philosophical topic chosen for the year, with special emphasis on integrating distinct philosophical perspectives and explaining that understanding orally;
2. to improve the skills in writing a philosophical paper, including the stages of research and revision;
3. to learn how to design a research project suitable for the RMA thesis;
4. to learn how to write a grant proposal for research funding;
5. to develop the ability to write about philosophy for a wider audience;
6. to draw on what has been learned in the course to engage with current philosophical research projects.     </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: A practical internship offers an opportunity to get to know one of the fields of the job market where students of PPE can end up in, and for you to participate in the labour process. You apply your gained knowledge and skills during an internship. An internship preferably takes place at an institution or company outside of the faculty.

IMPORTANT: you should read the information and the internship guide, to be found at https://students.uu.nl/en/hum/philosophy-politics-and-economics-ppe/curriculum/internships All procedures and rules are specified there.

Once you have found a suitable internship, you have to write an internship workplan (guidelines to be found at the same site). The workplan should include a description of the internship position, motivation and learning goals.
You should then contact the internship coordinator, who can give you advice if necessary. They will then find you a supervising lecturer.

During the internship you keep a log in which you, depending on what you and your supervising lecturer agreed on, write down daily or weekly notes, work reports, reports of meetings, etc. During the internship you send your updated log to your supervising lecturer via email. The lecturer provides feedback in order to help you with your learning process and your progress. The log is a way of helping you lay the foundations of the internship report, which you write in order to conclude your internship.

The final responsibility of grading the internship lies with the supervising lecturer. The lecturer will make a distinction between your performance during the internship and the final products (internship report and any products) you have handed in. The internship supervisor’s judgment (on your day-to-day performance) is also taken into account and can add or detract a maximum of 0,5 from your final grade.</body>

column1: <body>This course aims to develop citizenship, critical reflexivity, societal engagement, as well as the ability to bridge scholarship and societal practice.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In PPE in Society students are invited to bridge the gap between academia and the ‘outside world’. By engaging with societal partners and approaching problems from a systemic perspective, they will learn to engage with wicked questions. In doing so they will explore the contrasts as well as overlaps between scholarship and engagement, between macro and micro, and between thinking and doing. In doing so, students will be challenged to develop critical citizenship through reflexive practice.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Please note: the time slot shown here is not yet final, and may still be modified until 20 September 2023

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Please note: the information in the course manual is binding.
This course covers the fundamental principles in chemical and physical oceanography, which are necessary for the interpretation of paleoceanographic records.
After this course you will have:

column2: • knowledge about modern physical and chemical ocean processes;
• skills to identify and reconstruct paleoceanograhic scenarios on the basis of real scientific data;
• improved your general academic skills, such as report preparation and data presentation.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will be taught in this format for the last time in academic year 2023-2024.
The course Paleoceanography is part of the Bachelor program Earth Sciences, with a focus on the track Earth Climate and Life.

GEO2-1218  gives an overview of the mechanisms governing physical and chemical ocean processes. The course prepares students for other subjects that follow in the track “Oceans and Climate”. Paleoceanography has become an important discipline within the field of climate research, since it provides important benchmarks of climate variability, its amplitudes and timescales. A solid knowledge of modern ocean processes is necessary in order to interpret reconstructions of the past.

The course consists of lectures and computer-based practicals. The practicals can be found on Blackboard together with spreadsheets needed for the exercises. Relevant background information, literature, and lecture slides will be put on Blackboard as well.
The course is subdivided into two parts:

column2: • Teamwork: practical problems will be worked on in pairs of students, who have to organize and distribute tasks between them
• Report writing: practical results have to be handed-in in short report format
• Data presentation: students will practice the presentation (plotting) of real scientific datasets
• Software skills: students will use spreadsheet software Excel during the practicals

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/230836,2023,Paleoceanography and climate variability,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['M. Ziegler'],,Course goals

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Please note: the information in the course manual is binding.
On the basis of realistic scientific data, by the end of the course, student will:

column2: • be trained to identify, interpret and reconstruct the role of the ocean in past changes in climate;
• be trained to identify, interpret and reconstruct paleoclimate and variations there in;
• be trained in general academic skills such as writing reports, presenting scientific concepts.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

(Paleo)ocean circulation during different climatic regimes and related proxy variability will be discussed while sequentially introducing different concepts and aspects. Theory and application of marine proxies will be illustrated by relevant case studies. In particular the Glacial world will be contrasted to the (present-day) Interglacial, and compared to high-frequency (e.g. El-Nino) paleoceanographic and proxies variations. Amongst the aspects to be discussed are: Glacial climate and its forcing; sediment dating techniques; paleoproductvity; pCO2 reconstruction; oxygenation; sea surface temperature; deep water circulation; and proxy preservation. Current important scientific questions will be addressed and different view points discussed. The course teaches students hands on scientific research so that they can ‘hit the ground running’ in climate related projects.

column2: • Ability to work in the team: Presentations, practicals and final research proposal are organized in teams. Students have to distribute tasks, organize the workflow and are responsible for the time planning.
• Problem solving: students receive data from previous sea-going expeditions and have to use different approaches to unravel past ocean and climate change.

• Verbal communication skills: 50% of the lectures are based on the so-called flip-class room concept in which the students have to transfer expert knowledge to to their peers. This implies that they alos have to set teaching goals, plan a lecture and present the lecture. Subjects are setup in such a way as to stimulate discussion and participate in the discussion.

• Analytical / quantitative skills: students have to setup and run simple numerical (inverse) models to to analyse their data. These model runs are subsequently quantitatively compared with real world data.

• Technical skills: using the computer programmes Excel for handling large data sets and data transformations. By regularly comparing different analytical approaches students get insight in the prossibilities and limitations of the different techniques.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: To gain insights into the principles and mechanisms of past climate change and the effect of climate changes on marine and terrestrial ecosystems. </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>The course will introduce the student into the trends, oscillations and aberrations within the climate system over the past 100 million years. Special emphasis will be on the following topics:

column2: • astronomical forcing of ice ages and monsoons,
• extreme and abrupt climate changes during the Eocene greenhouse world
• 10 computer exercises given during 12 classes of 90 minutes each.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/230819,2023,Paleoenvironments,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['prof. dr. F. Wagner-Cremer', 'T. Giesecke, PhD']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of the course you can:

column2: • Understand and interpret global environmental and climatological processes (solar insolation, circulation, vegetation, CO2­, nutrients, human impact) and their impact on terrestrial biota (flora and fauna)
• Recognize and apply morphological traits of key fossil groups used in palaeoecology (pollen & spores, leaf macrofossils, diatoms)
• Use palaoecological methods to determine and interpret the characteristics of sedimentary archives.
• Apply and interpret quantitative palaeoecological methods (pollen influx, age-depth modeling, stomatal frequency analysis, transfer functions).

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course provides the basis for the study of present and past continental (terrestrial and aquatic) ecosystems with biological proxies. Emphasis is on the interaction between geosphere/hydrosphere - biosphere ‐ atmosphere in response to environmental change on different temporal and spatial scales. Based on modern analogues we use palaeoecological methods to reconstruct changes in ecosystems on different ecologically and geologically important time-scales (10-1-107 years). Important aspects are the distinction between natural and anthropogenic changes in the late Quaternary (i.e. the past 15,000 years) and their implications for current and future environmental change. The course is in English depending on foreign student enrolment.

column2: • Ability to work in the team: poster presentations and reports are prepared in teams of variable size (2-4). Students have to distribute tasks, organize the workflow and are responsible for the time planning.

• Problem solving: students together produce new data from proxy analyses and have to use the literature resources, practical software skills and the background information to analyse and interpret the data, and describe it in two reports.
• Verbal communication skills: Students present a short pitch for their poster highlighting the general problem addressed and the controversy regarding the topic.
• Analytical / quantitative skills: multivariate statistics and transfer function development and use, and interpretation of multiproxy palaeoenvironmental data.

• Technical skills: Students learn to perform hands-on microscopy techniques for pollen, leaf morphology and diatom analyses. Using the computer programs Excel, C2 and Tilia they will process and plot the gathered data, producing quantitative reconstructions and interpretations.
• Writing skills: the reports are expected to be concise, well written scientific reports for which feedback is provided on both content and scientific language use.

column1: The course is subdivided into three modules: 1) palaeohysiology of plants , 2) vegetation reconstruction with palynology, and 3) paleolimnology with diatom analysis. All modules aim on the introduction of biological palaeo-proxies and the interpretation of the results in terms of environmental and climatic changes.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/230859,2023,Paleomagnetism,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. L.V. de Groot'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Please note: the information in the course manual is binding.

To understand the role of the Earth's ancient magnetic field as recorded in rocks in a wide range of Earth scientific disciplines. Examples include geodynamics & plate tectonics, time scales, geomagnetic variations and behaviour of the geodynamo through geological time, and application to (paleo) environmental magnetism and climate proxies.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The paleomagnetism course deals with the integrated geophysical (geomagnetism, intensity of magnetic field), geochemical (rock magnetism, environmental magnetism), and geological (magnetostratigraphy and tectonic rotations) fundamentals of magnetism in Earth Sciences. Application of these techniques will be explained through practical assignments, hands-on exercises and data analyses.

Geophysical aspects: geomagnetic variations at all time scales. from secular variation, tiny wiggles and excursions of the field, to reversals (including magnetostratigraphy), reversal frequency, Superchrons and paleointensity reconstructions. At short time scales (100-5000 years), geomagnetic variations typically reflect core processes. Variations at longer time scales, however, must reflect mantle and core/mantle boundary processes. Hence, what do these variations tell us about processes in the internal, deep Earth?

Geochemical aspects: the magnetic carriers in rocks. How and why do rocks record the geomagnetic field? We discuss magnetism at the atomic level and link it to macroscopic properties of mineral and rock magnetism. We explain why the natural remanent magnetisation (NRM) can be geologically stable - i.e. for tens of billions of years, and how to extract this information from rock samples. This involves both laboratory and field tests, and we discuss how rocks acquire their NRM.

Geological aspects: stratigraphic and geodynamic applications: There are applications of paleomagnetism and rock magnetism in a wide range of earths scientific disciplines. Time Scales: the role of accurate dating is crucial in Earth Sciences, and, here, magnetostratigraphy forms a powerful part of the dating toolbox. It can be used in combination with other dating methods, of which astrochronology is the one providing the highest accuracy and precision. Applications of time scales have a wide range: from determining changes in (paleo)environment and (paleo)climate (and the corresponding influence on mineral magnetic changes in sediments) to dating tectonic phases and climate change, and their respective impacts on the geological archive. Geodynamic applications, from the scale of continents to regional studies: block rotations and crustal movement, paleomagnetic poles and apparent polar wander (APWP), hotspot versus paleomagnetic reference frames. In some case studies, there will be emphasis on the recognition of tectonic versus climatic processes in the development of sedimentary basins.

The first part of the course will be directed to a combinaton of lectures, excercises and scientific class discussions including presentations by students. Different topics will include: Geomagnetism, Statistics and models, Rock magnetism, Paleointensity, Tectonics and Magnetostratigraphy. The second part of the course will deal with selecting new individual research topics which will be evaluated by writing a 4 page scientific proposal of the students own topic of (paleomagnetic) interest and an oral presentation defending the proposal for the class audience. Students will be informed about key papers, practical exercises or assignments, and the approach at the beginning of and during the course.

The course Paleomagnetism is highly recommended for students of the master programme Earth, Structure and Dynamics, tracks 1) Basins, orogens and the crust-lithosphere system, 2) Earth materials, 3) Physics of the deep Earth and planets and the programme Earth, Life and Climate, track Integrated stratigraphy and sedimentary systems. The course is meant for students who are particularly interested in the fundamentals and applications of the geomagnetic field and its registration in the rock record.

column2: • Ability to work in the team: students will work in small teams on a literature topic that should be jointly presented in class and submitted as written document.
• Written communication skills: students will write their own research proposal that will be evaluated on the topics of quality, innovation and feasibility.
• Verbal communication skills: students will have to present and defend their research proposal in an oral communication for a broad scientific audience.
• Analytical /quantitative skills: analytical expertise will be obtained during topical computer exercises.
• Technical skills: using the computer programmes Excel, and several paleomagnetic programs available on Paleomagnetism.org.
• Problem solving: several case studies must be solved during the exercises and different approaches will have to be used to solve these research problems.
• Initiative: students will have to define, elaborate and solve their own research question; all to be worked out in detail in an individual research proposal.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/230707,2023,Palaeontology - fauna,Dutch, English",Faculty of Geosciences,,"['dr. E.B. Jarochowska', 'prof. dr. A.S. Schulp']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Please note: the information in the course manual is binding.
The aims of this course are to provide students with knowledge of and insight in the use of fossils - invertebrates and vertebrates - to reconstruct geological time and evolution of life.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will be taught in this format for the last time in academic year 2023-2024.
At the end of the course the student can:

column2: • identify main group of marine animal fossils and the most important groups of terrestrial fossil vertebrates;
• apply the geological time scale and understand studies using it;
• reconstruct the age and environment from the most characteristic groups of fossils;
• compare information obtained from fossil findings and from studies on extant animals and explain the differences;
• propose hypotheses on the preservation or non-preservation of fossils based on their knowledge of the environment and properties of the fossils;
• reconstruct environmental changes from stratigraphic successions of fossils using the nearest living relative approach;
• explain how the record of evolution is distorted by the geological record;
• name the largest extinction events in the Earth history and explain what evolutionary rates are.

column1: The course involves one excursion around Utrecht where students find fossils in building stones and answer questions about them. This exercise requires a phone and some amount of mobile data.
The practicals alternate between analyzing fossil specimens and computer tasks. Some of these tasks involve running code in Python. The codes are provided, but may need to be modified by students.
Blackboard is used to submit assignments and the exams are Remindo test with a combination of multiple-choice, single-choice and open questions.

The main effort in the course consists of weekly assignments that account for the bulk of self-study and the grade. Each assignment should be completed within a week from the practical, unless indicated otherwise. After receiving feedback on the grade, each student has one chance to resubmit a corrected version of the assignment.
Late submissions are accepted exclusively until the 8th of April to make it possible to issue course grade on time. Late submissions are graded with a penalty of -15% of the grade.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>This course offers a broad overview on the fossil record of plants with special emphasis on evolution and biodiversity changes since the Palaeozoic.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course basic principles of plant evolution from the Palaeozoic to present-day are taught. The major steps of terrestrialization are placed into a comprehensive overview on feedbacks between large-scale geosphere processes such as plate tectonics, atmosphere-biosphere interactions, and the global carbon cycle through time. The second goal is to critically reflect on natural dynamics of biodiversity versus modern biodiversity loss, the human induced “mass-exctinction” of the 21st century.
In weekly modules the major periods of the geological history are covered.
2 introduction lectures (2x45min each) per week provide the conceptual framework on vegetation history during the geological periods.
Practicals introduce the topics of the assignments, which include:

The assignments are rock and fossil labs, computer aided labs and a one day practical held in the botanical garden. In depth knowledge is obtained through additional computer home-works, and required readings. For these work packages self-study time is designated.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Studenten die de cursus met goed gevolg afronden, hebben een overzicht van de belangrijkste ontwikkelingen van de westerse kunst en architectuur van de Grieken tot heden, beschikken over kennis van de belangrijkste kunsthistorische terminologie en hebben inzicht in de diverse aspecten, methoden en vraagstukken van de wetenschappelijke beoefening van de kunstgeschiedenis.
Onderzoekskader: je verwerft historiografische kennis over de kunsthistorische canon. Je leert hoe de kunsthistorische canon tot stand is gekomen en je leert deze kritisch te bevragen.
Analyse: je leert visuele analyses maken van kunstwerken (schilderkunst en sculptuur) en gebouwen. Je zet je eerste stappen in het leren dateren en chronologisch ordenen van kunst en architectuur.
Betoog en vorm: Je schrijft een academische rapportage van je visuele analyse.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Deze inleidende kunsthistorische overzichtscursus biedt een serie chronologisch gerangschikte hoor- en werkcolleges langs de hoofdlijnen en hoogtepunten van de westerse kunstgeschiedenis vanaf de Oude Grieken tot en met de 21ste eeuw. Elk college behandelt een volgende kunsthistorische fase. Daarbij wordt aandacht besteed aan de middelen die in de kunstgeschiedenis worden gebruikt om tot ordening en overzicht te komen, zoals de verdeling in perioden, het onderscheiden van stijlen, de toeschrijving van kunstwerken aan kunstenaars, en de indeling van de kunstwerken volgens de toegepaste technieken. We oefenen met het belangrijkste gereedschap van de kunsthistoricus: de visuele analyse.

Bij dit vak gaan we op excursie. Hieraan zijn kosten verbonden (reiskosten en entree museum). Studenten kunstgeschiedenis wordt aangeraden een museumjaarkaart of een ICOM pas (https://icom.nl/nl/lidmaatschap/individueel-lidmaatschap) aan te schaffen. Met deze laatste pas kan je gratis musea in binnen en buitenland bezoeken.

Let op: Niet-Kunstgeschiedenis studenten die een overzicht van de Kunstgeschiedenis willen volgen, kunnen terecht bij de cursus The Story of Art (cursuscode: KU1V18001 - deze cursus heeft geen aparte werkgroepen en wordt specifiek gedoceerd voor niet-kunstgeschiedenis studenten).

column1: <body>Upon finishing this course, you will have:

column2: • advanced knowledge and insight into the the main conceptual perspectives and strategies that are useful for examining the field of Youth, Education and Society.
• awareness of and understanding of the consequences of these conceptual perspectives to apply them in practice.
• the ability to argue about and discuss these perspectives.
• become aware of your own epistemological and normative position in the field of Youth, Education & Society
• developed the ability to compose your own written position and argumentation on these perspectives.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This founding course for the Master's programme discusses the main conceptual perspectives and strategies that are useful for examining the field of Youth, Education and Society. It offers theoretical perspectives (paradigms) for studying social educational issues and teaches you how to apply those in order to make the connection between scientific research, policy, and practice. In this course, paradigms are defined as theoretical perspectives, a set of coherent ideas or a philosophy of education that helps us to understand the field and informs our professional actions in it. Awareness of and understanding paradigms and understanding the consequences for applying them in practice are key aspects of the course. For instance, you will be familiarized with a community psychology perspective in youth care, which is contrasted with individualistic approaches based on early stage identification of risks. You will learn how a ‘critical pedagogy’ approach differs from a more technocratic approach of education in which efficiency is foregrounded and in which the political and value oriented nature of education is ignored.

In addition, you will learn to develop a global perspective in thinking about these issues. You learn to think and act as a scientist and a professional when dealing with or working with scientific knowledge, intervention programs and policies in (inter)national contexts that are culturally diverse. You will learn to deal with cultural diversity in the context of knowledge transfer between communities that are geographically or culturally (far) apart. We raise the question ‘What is the value of scientific theories that were developed in Western settings for other parts of the world or for situations of migration?’ And  ‘How can we think about pedagogical knowledge from a more global perspective given the increased contact between different regions in the world?’ .

Apart from widening your perspective cross-nationally and cross-culturally, this founding course deals with issues of ethnic and social conflict and inequality on the one hand, and methodologies for inclusion and finding common ground, overcoming problematic aspects difference on the other. Perspectives and methodologies related to inclusion, equity, democratic citizenship and social justice will play an important part in the course. We will pay attention to the analyses of diversity and divergence/polarization, inequality and social justice at a variety of scales. This could range from what the effects of policies, systems and infrastructures are on inequality in education and care to how inequality can be represented in more micro settings such as in learning contexts for literacy, numeracy and multi-lingualism.

In line with the YES program, the course teaches students about the policy context of the aforementioned issues, and teaches you what the afore mentioned issues mean for a policy (making) perspective. In addition, students are stimulated to contribute to and form their opinion about public debates on the afore mentioned issues in a critically reflective. Also, students learn to become reflective of their own normative positions in these matters.
Students will choose for one of the 3 following seminars, and their choice for the seminar coincides with their track choice.

The YEP (Youth Policy, Education & Prevention) seminar  you will further analyze key  paradigms in the field of Youth, Education & Society in welfare societies, as related to issues of youth wellbeing, youth care and education. Paying attention to the dilemmas of modern parenthood in the context of today’s individualized society, you learn to understand, analyze and discuss policy and programmatic responses to those dilemma’s as well as alternatives for those responses.  Taking knowledge of the community based paradigm, that focuses on the social settings, systems and institutions to optimize the wellbeing of youth, you will learn to contrast this approach to  ‘at risk’ or pathology oriented perspectives. You will analyze and debate the potential of community based programmes, for instance,  to prevent child maltreatment or as alternatives for professional care.

Taking knowledge of critical pedagogy perspectives, you will also learn to critically evaluate the position of scientific research in supporting professional practice and policies in the sector. You will analyze different positions in this respect while contrasting more technologically inspired ‘evidence based’ approaches to those that claim youth care and education must be seen as fundamentally moral and political practices that need continuous contestation by all parties involved. An important goal of the seminar is to become aware of your own epistemological and normative position as a researcher and professional in the field of Youth, Education and Society. You will learn to take position in guided discussion groups, and write a position paper.

In the PID (Pedagogy & International Development) seminar International Development is a key theme.  We will focus on the question how the development of youth and children can be optimized when working cross-culturally from a scientific, professional and policy perspective. Within this general theme, we address themes as health, care and education and work as interrelated but separate subthemes. We study programmatic and policy attempts to improve the living circumstances and educational environments of youth, and analyse the scientific bases that underlies these. Special target groups, such as child soldiers, street children, children with disabilities or children affected by AIDS will be addressed, while also paying attention to the situation of immigrant children and youth in welfare countries. You will examine Western ideas on international development, as well as the need to reshape these ideas. You will consider how local differences between the lives of young people in the Western world and the non-Western world, for example, determine their opportunities, developmental prospects and limitations. In this process, you will learn how to think from multiple perspectives. For example, more instrumental and technological approaches are contrasted with more critical views on international collaboration. An important goal of the seminar is to become aware of your own epistemological and normative position as a researcher and professional in the field of Youth, Education and Society. You will learn to take position in guided discussion groups, and write a position paper.

The EFIS (Education For Inclusive Societies) seminar will thematically zoom into the increasing tension and polarization between different ethno-cultural groups in schools and classrooms as well as into how these operate in other domains or institutions relevant for the socialization of youth such as the family, the neighborhood, youth clubs or mosques. Students gain theoretical insights, analytical tools and learn about hands on methodologies that are relevant for educational settings, youth care, youth welfare, related support services and policy work.

You will learn about facts and figures, theories, models of understanding of (the construction of) difference, in-group, out-group mechanisms, polarization (including radicalization), inequality, disadvantage, stigma and discrimination as well as about theories and models of inclusion, recognition, emancipation of minorities, multiculturalism, overcoming difference, and democratic citizenship as applied to schools, families and neighborhoods and related services and policies. In addition, in the seminar we pay attention to the methodologies and interventions to analyze and optimize concrete practices and issues, such as inter-ethnic learning situations, conflict and diversity management, school identity issues, quality measures in early childhood education for minorities, and/or family and neighborhood based interventions such as parenting programs for minorities. An important goal of the seminar is to become aware of your own epistemological and normative position as a researcher and professional in the field of Youth, Education and Society. You will learn to take position in guided discussion groups, and write a position paper.

Through your own reading of the literature, attending the lectures, as well as discussing the literature in the seminars, you will gain an advanced knowledge and insight into the main conceptual perspectives and strategies that are useful for the field of Youth, Education and Society (goal 1). In the seminars as well as in the lectures, students will be made aware of the consequences of these conceptual perspectives for policy measures and concrete interventions (goal 2). The seminars will invite and oblige you as students to critically discuss the literature, ask questions and argue for particular positions (goal 3). The position paper, as well as the discussions in the seminar will help you to become aware of your own epistemological and normative position (goal 4) while writing the position paper will enable you to develop a written position and the underlying argumentation (goal 5).
Not applicable. The course is not open to other students outside the master program.

column1: After completion of the course, the student:

column2: • has in-depth knowledge of the concept of modern particle physics
• knows the principles of scattering theory, and how Fermi's golden rule leads to a prescription for the calculation of cross sections and decay widths using Feynman diagrams
• is able to apply scattering theory to quantum electrodynamics and the weak interaction
• knows the concept of local gauge invariance and is able to apply it to describe the unified electroweak interaction
• understands the theory of electroweak symmetry breaking in the Standard Model, Higgs field and Higgs boson production and detection at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN
• is familiar with discovery papers and experimental techniques of elementary particles and fundamental forces in the Standard Model of particle physics
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Particle physics takes a truly fundamental look at the laws of Nature. It describes the building blocks of our material world and the interactions between them. This course presents the state of the art of the theory of particle physics, the Standard Model, with most of its ingredients. The Standard Model is an approach towards a unified description of forces, which are understood as mediated by exchange particles, and its structure is built on quantum field theory. During the last decades, the Standard Model has proven to be extremely successful with agreement with experimental data to very high precision. The relatively recent discovery of the Higgs boson is seen as one of the last cornerstones of the Standard Model.

In spite of its success, there are still many open questions, the most important ones related to the two facts that 1) only three of the four fundamental interactions are incorporated, i.e. gravitation is not described, and that 2) a real unification of the forces, which many researchers expect to happen asymptotically, has still not been reached, pointing to so-called “beyond-the-Standard-Model” physics.
The picture of the Standard Model is completed with a follow-up course, Particle Physics 2.

The lectures start with an introduction into the concept of modern particle physics. After that scattering theory is introduced starting from Fermi's golden rule leading to a prescription for the calculation of cross sections and decay widths using Feynman diagrams for relativistic particles. The scattering theory is then applied to the case of quantum electrodynamics, first for spinless particles (bosons) and then for particles with spin ½ particles (fermions). The weak interaction is discussed including the experimental constraints to this theory. The concept of local gauge invariance is introduced and applied to describe the unified electroweak interaction resulting in the calculation of the process: e + + e- → (γ, Z) →  μ+  + μ- as an example. In the second part of the course some 'hot' issues in modern particle physics are presented: electroweak symmetry breaking in the Standard Model, the Higgs field, Higgs

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After completion of the course, the student:

column2: • understands the basic ingredients of the strong interactions, and the main differences of the structure of the corresponding theory compared to other fundamental interactions
• knows about the experimental evidence for quarks and gluons
• understands the symmetry properties related to quarks and gluons and the colour charge
• is able to apply scattering theory to problems of the strong interaction
• knows about hadrons and their phenomenology
• knows about the phenomenology of non-perturbative processes of the strong interaction
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Particle physics takes a truly fundamental look at the laws of Nature. It describes the building blocks of our material world and the interactions between them. This course presents the state of the art of the theory of particle physics, the Standard Model, with most of its ingredients. The Standard Model is an approach towards a unified description of forces, which are understood as mediated by exchange particles, and its structure is built on quantum field theory. During the last decades, the Standard Model has proven to be extremely successful with agreement with experimental data to very high precision. The relatively recent discovery of the Higgs boson is seen as one of the last cornerstones of the Standard Model.

In spite of its success, there are still many open questions, the most important ones related to the two facts that 1) only three of the four fundamental interactions are incorporated, i.e. gravitation is not described, and that 2) a real unification of the forces, which many researchers expect to happen asymptotically, has still not been reached, pointing to so-called “beyond-the-Standard-Model” physics.
The picture of the Standard Model is completed with a follow-up course, Particle Physics 2.

This course covers one of the four fundamental interactions in the Standard Model of particle physics, the strong interaction, in detail. The strong interaction, which is effectively perceived via the binding of atomic nuclei, is now fundamentally described as an interaction between quarks. It is responsible for a wealth of different phenomena, from the description of the fundamental constituents of the theory, the quarks and gluons, at high energy to the low energy bound states, namely hadrons and ultimately nuclei. In part the phenomena can be treated perturbatively, and this version of the theory leads to a high-precision description of experimental results. At the same time, there is a whole realm of strong interaction physics, for which perturbative calculations cannot be used, which poses interesting puzzles, last but not least with phenomena as confinement and chiral-symmetry breaking. The strong interaction is necessary to understand all of the physics at modern particle accelerators such as the LHC, and it is also responsible for an exciting collective feature in particle physics: the phase transition to the quark-gluon plasma, which is thought to be present in the early universe.

The lectures start with a review of the low-energy evidence of the strong interaction and with a reminder of scattering theory as discussed in the course Particle Physics 1. Then, electron-proton scattering is discussed together with the concepts of form factors and structure functions, and the implications for the parton model. Symmetries relevant for the strong interaction are introduced and are applied to the quark model. Next, the quantum field theory of the strong interaction, quantum chromodynamics (QCD), is described together with applications of perturbative QCD.

Finally, the course will also review some of the non-perturbative aspects of QCD, in particular parton distribution functions and their quantum evolution, and hadrons, including the process of hadronization. It will continue with a discussion of colour confinement and chiral symmetry breaking. For this latter part, effective model descriptions, like the string model and the bag model, will also be introduced.

column1: Pathologie (ziekteleer) bestudeert het ontstaan en verloop van ziektes. Hierbij moet worden gerealiseerd dat een ziekte geen statisch plaatje is maar een proces. In dit blok gaan we aan de hand van vier hoofdthema’s de pathologie bestuderen van verschillende ziektebeelden. Deze vier hoofdthema’s zijn Celpathologie, Immunopathologie, Oncopathologie en Cardiovasculaire pathologie. Per thema wordt er een mix aangeboden van (klinische) achtergronden van ziektes en wetenschappelijk onderzoek (experimentele pathologie). Naast overzichtscolleges en digitale microscopiepractica zullen er verschillende onderzoekers komen vertellen over hun onderzoek. In verschillende teamopdrachten gaan studenten zelf de koppeling maken tussen ziektemechanismen en wetenschappelijk onderzoek (research-based). In de hoofdopdracht krijgen studenten een ‘challenge’ om een (onbegrepen) ziektebeeld nader te onderzoeken, waarbij ook de patiënt(en), de behandelend artsen en de onderzoekers worden betrokken. Academische vaardigheden zullen worden getraind aan de hand van schriftelijke essays en poster- en/of mondelinge presentaties. Studenten met de beste ideeën krijgen de mogelijkheid om deze binnen het laboratorium verder uit te werken.
Basale kennis op de volgende vakgebieden: Celbiologie, Histologie, Immunologie en Oncologie.
Na afronding van dit blok is de student in staat:

column2: • de belangrijkste principes en mechanismen in de pathologie van cellulaire processen, ontstekingen, wondgenezing, tumoren en circulatiestoornissen te benoemen;
• de belangrijkste histologische kenmerken in de pathologie van cellulaire processen, ontstekingen, wondgenezing, tumoren en circulatiestoornissen te herkennen en te benoemen;
• de koppeling te maken tussen ziekteprocessen en wetenschappelijk onderzoek.

column1: Na afronding van dit blok is de student in staat:

column2: • om de algemeen gangbare werkwijzen en technieken in de experimentele pathologie te beschrijven en toe te passen;
• een wetenschappelijke essay op te stellen ter nadere beschrijving en bestudering van een pathobiologisch probleem;
• een goed onderbouwde poster/presentatie te maken aangaande een pathobiologisch probleem.

column1: Na afronding van dit blok is de student in staat om:

column2: • samen te werken zodanig dat het best haalbare groepsresultaat wordt behaald;
• zich kritisch op te stellen richting zichzelf maar ook richting medestudenten.

column1: Per hoofdthema zijn er enkele opgenomen hoorcolleges (zelfstudie), 2-4 introductie hoorcolleges, 2-4 digitale microscopiepractica en 2 hoorcolleges over een specifiek researchonderwerp. In groepen zullen de studenten verschillende opdrachten nader uitwerken (vorm van team-based learning), waarbij de docent/onderzoeker beschikbaar zal zijn als expert. Er zal worden gerapporteerd in de vorm van essays, poster en mondelinge presentaties. Het geheel wordt aangevuld met een aantal site-visits en demo's. De totale contacttijd is ongeveer 5-10 uur per week.

Per hoofdthema wordt een korte MC-toets afgenomen en worden opdrachten verstrekt die in groepen nader worden uitgewerkt in de vorm van een essay, poster en/of mondelinge presentatie. Ook zal er toetsing plaatsvinden d.m.v. een aantal essayvragen in combinatie met de opdracht tot het schrijven van een hypothese en een onderzoeksvoorstel voor een specifiek pathologisch probleem (probleem wordt tijdens de toets bekend gemaakt). Deelname aan de groepsessies, de practica en het eerste hoorcollege zijn verplicht, ook voor recidivisten. Weging: 3x Individuele readiness assurance test (iRAT) (20%), 3x Team readiness assurance test (tRAT) (5%), 3x Groepsopdracht (25%), Posterpresentatie of PowerPoint presentatie (eindwerkstuk) (20%), Inzet groepswerk (10%), Eindtoets (20%). Het predicaat ‘voldoende’ geldt bij een cijfermatige score van 5.5 of hoger. Als bijkomende voorwaarde geldt dat voor geen van bovengenoemde onderdelen een cijfer lager dan 5.0 mag worden gescoord.

column1: Pathology is a discipline of medicine that adds great benefit by integrating in vivo, biochemical, and molecular data. It is not possible to diagnose systemic illness, co-morbidities, and proximate causes of death without the morphologic context provided by pathology. Mice, and in particular genetically modified models, present unique considerations because these modifications are affected by background strain genetics, husbandry, and experimental conditions.

column1: Het patiëntperspectievenprogramma heeft als doel om aankomend artsen te leren de zorg zo te organiseren dat deze aansluit bij de behoeften en de verwachtingen van de patiënt van straks. Zij leren met patiënten en hun naasten te communiceren, hen in staat te stellen tot regie over de eigen gezondheid en gedeelde besluitvorming toe te passen.

Hiervoor is het nodig dat studenten o.a. leren zich te verplaatsen in de situatie van de patiënt, leren een band op te bouwen met de patiënt, leren de patiënt te informeren en inzicht hebben in het gehele zorgproces. Daarnaast is reflectie op eigen denken en doen en open staan voor feedback van patiënten en collega’s van belang.
Het patiëntperspectievenprogramma benut verschillende onderwijsvormen waarin patiënten actief participeren om deze vaardigheden te ontwikkelen.

In elk studiejaar maakt de student één of meer opdrachten. Deze opdrachten zijn ingebed in de blokken of LINKs van het geneeskundecurriculum. Er wordt gereflecteerd op de opdrachten tijdens intervisiebijeenkomsten. Daarnaast volgt de student patiëntcolleges.
Het PatiëntPerspectievenProgramma is een leerlijn die loopt van Bachelor jaar 3 t/m Master jaar 2.

Aan het eind van elk studiejaar wordt gecontroleerd of de opdrachten zijn gemaakt en of de verplichte intervisiebijeenkomsten zijn bijgewoond. Het PPP wordt beoordeeld met een voldoende of onvoldoende.
Prof. dr. J. Frenkel (j.frenkel@umcutrecht.nl)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The patient perspective program aims to teach future doctors to practice health care in a way that it aligns with patients’ expectations and preferences. Students learn to communicate with patients and their family, to support patient’s self-management and to actively involve and collaborate with patients regarding decisions related to their health, while taking into account the patient’s preference for involvement.

This requires students to recognize the patients’ perspective on health and healthcare, to build partnerships with patients, to be able to provide tailored information and to have an in-depth knowledge of the care process. Reflection on own beliefs and behavior, and being receptive to feedback from patients and colleagues are important enablers.
The patient perspective program  comprises various educational interventions in which patients actively participate, in order to foster patient-centeredness amongst students.

Every academic year, the student makes assignments. These assignments are embedded in the courses or clerkships of the medical curriculum. The assignments are discussed during small group teaching sessions or individually by the clerkship supervisor. Furthermore, the student follows patient lectures.
The patient perspective program is a longitudinal course, from Bachelor year 3 to Master year 3.
Students pass when they complete the assignments sufficiently and attend the mandatory teaching sessions.
Students fail when they did not complete the assignments, insufficiently completed the assignments or did not attend the mandatory teaching sessions.

<body>The purpose of the tutoring system is to support the student with respect to their (a) commitment to their educational program, (b) development of and striving towards their goals, expectations, capacities en preferences regarding their education, (c) development of a professional attitude, (d) educational progress, (e) choices regarding their education, and (f) career perspectives.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Alle psychologiestudenten gaan na hun eerste jaar over naar een nieuw College en een nieuwe tutor.

Dit nieuwe Senior College heeft een verbredend en verdiepend karakter ten opzichte van zowel de studieloopbaan als de vakinhoudelijke stof. Het is de gemeenschap van studenten waar zij t/m hun derde jaar bij zullen horen en mee samen zullen werken bij het onderhouden van hun motivatie, exploreren van toekomstmogelijkheden, en voorbereiden op de arbeidsmarkt. Elk College komt minstens één maal per onderwijsblok bij elkaar. De studenten geven in overleg met hun tutor (en binnen de grenzen van de doelen van het tutoraat) zelf invulling aan het programma.

De tutor begeleidt de activiteiten van het Senior College en volgt de studievoortgang van de individuele studenten. De tutor helpt de studenten uit het College om zich thuis te voelen bij de opleiding, tot weloverwogen keuzes te komen, en zo het beste uit zichzelf en anderen te halen. De tutor nodigt elke student minstens één maal per jaar uit voor een individueel gesprek. Daarnaast kunnen studenten zelf ook afspraken met hun tutor maken.

Elk Senior College heeft een eigen Blackboard-pagina van waaruit de tutor en studenten van het College met elkaar kunnen communiceren. Daarnaast worden studenten via de Blackboard-omgeving van de cursus 'Tutoraat Verdiepend' vanuit de opleiding geïnformeerd over onderwerpen die relevant zijn voor iedereen: voorlichtingen, evenementen en andere belangrijke zaken.

column1: This course focuses on different types of interventions, policies and actions that aim to resolve or end intractable conflict in the period after the Cold War until the present. It seeks to improve your understanding of
- the different types of policies and interventions in the field of peace and security
- the underlying assumptions on peace and security
- the political contexts in which interventions and policies take place
- the key debates about these interventions and policies

- the different ways to analyse these interventions and policies, using different analytical lenses, including more traditional approaches (policy cycle), rational choice approaches, and interpretative approaches. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course deals with different forms of policy, public action and international intervention and ‘engineering’ in and on situations of virulent conflict and/or endemic violence. It pays attention to the main debates about the policies and interventions of international actors in conflict affected countries, and discusses different ways to analyse these policies.
This course is for students in the MA Conflict Studies and Human Rights; students from other M.A. programmes can only enroll with consent of the programme coordinator.</body>

-  jouw visie op de pedagogische verantwoordelijkheid van leraar en school expliciteren en die met argumenten onderbouwen;
-  op systematische wijze gegevens verzamelen en analyseren voor de beantwoording van een leervraag over het eigen pedagogisch handelen in de praktijk;
-  jouw eigen functioneren zien als onderdeel van de interactie tussen leraar en leerling(en) en daarop reflecteren aan de hand van gegevens over die interactie;
-  het functioneren van (groepen) leerlingen analyseren vanuit een sociale systeembenadering;

-  expliciteren hoe je in jouw professionele handelen als docent rekening houdt met sociale contexten en systemen die de leefwereld vormen van leerlingen, in het bijzonder waar het gaat om het aspect van culturele diversiteit.
-  basiskennis van de ontwikkelingspsychologie in de fase van adolescentie vertalen naar jouw lespraktijk;
-  in jouw professionele handelen rekenschap geven van de maatschappelijke verantwoordelijkheid van het onderwijs in het algemeen en ten aanzien van burgerschapsvorming in het bijzonder.
